656416.sentence: So Will supposed that this was what the men were after, and knew he had to do something about it.

657343.sentence: Later that day, toward midnight in fact, Will was walking out of the city of Oxford, forty miles away. He was tired to his very bones.

658738.sentence: Will was stupefied with exhaustion, and he might have gone on to the north, or he might have laid his head on the grass under one of those trees and slept; but as he stood trying to clear his head, he saw a cat.

658850.sentence: She was a tabby, like Moxie. She padded out of a garden on the Oxford side of the road, where Will was standing.

658976.sentence: Will put down his tote bag and held out his hand, and the cat came up to rub her head against his knuckles, just as Moxie did.

659095.sentence: Of course, every cat behaved like that, but all the same Will felt such a longing for home that tears scalded his eyes.

659358.sentence: Will, still watching, saw the cat behave curiously.

659459.sentence: She reached out a paw to pat something in the air in front of her, something quite invisible to Will.

659559.sentence: Then she leaped backward, back arched and fur on end, tail held out stiffly. Will knew cat behavior.

659952.sentence: The cat stepped forward and vanished. Will blinked.

660996.sentence: But Will knew without the slightest doubt that that patch of grass on the other side was in a different world.

661931.sentence: The hot night was laden with the scent of flowers and with the salt smell of the sea. Will looked around carefully.

662886.sentence: Will lifted up his tattered tote bag and walked slowly across the road toward them, moving very carefully in case it all disappeared.

663156.sentence: Will had never been out of England, so he couldn’t compare it with anywhere he knew, but it was the kind of place where people came out late at night to eat and drink, to dance and enjoy music.

664780.sentence: Will found himself facing a harbor enclosed from the left by a stone breakwater and from the right by a headland on which a large building with stone columns and wide steps and ornate balconies stood floodlit among flowering trees and bushes.

664943.sentence: By now Will’s exhaustion had been wiped out.

665981.sentence: There were paths leading here and there among the lamp-hung oleander trees, but not a sound of life could be heard: no night birds singing, no insects, nothing but Will’s own footsteps.

666282.sentence: Will made his way there. The tide was halfway in, or halfway out, and a row of pedal boats was drawn up on the soft white sand above the high-water line.

666595.sentence: Will sat on the side of one of the pedal boats and kicked off his shoes, his cheap sneakers that were coming apart and cramping his hot feet.

667647.sentence: He had a whole world to hide in. For the first time since he’d run out of his front door that morning, Will began to feel secure.

668964.sentence: The air was hot and stuffy, and Will opened the glass door onto the balcony to let in the night air.

669299.sentence: Will left and looked in the other rooms: a little bathroom, a bedroom with a double bed.

670407.sentence: Will stood up slowly. “Who are you?”

671232.sentence: The stoat curled himself around her neck, and his dark eyes never left Will’s face.

671349.sentence: “You en’t ... You en’t been ...” “My name’s Will Parry,”  he said.

672329.sentence: In the kitchen Will found the ingredients for a casserole of chicken and onions and peppers, but they hadn’t been cooked, and in the heat they were smelling bad.

672504.sentence: Lyra came to look. “I didn’t know this was here,”  she said. “Oh! It’s cold.”

672804.sentence: Will felt he shouldn’t stare, though his head was ringing with the strangeness of it.

674612.sentence: She tipped the can into the saucepan and licked a finger, watching as Will shook salt and pepper into the eggs and cut a knob of butter from a package in the fridge into a cast-iron pan.

674856.sentence: Her dæmon, a cat again, was dipping his paw in it, too, but he backed away when Will came near.

674939.sentence: “It’s not cooked yet,”  Will said, taking it away. “When did you last have a meal?”

675573.sentence: “Find a couple of plates,”  he said, and Lyra obediently did so.

676175.sentence: Will ate slowly. He’d given her most of the beans, but even so he took much longer than she did.

677649.sentence: Will looked at him with wide wary eyes, and the girl saw his glance.

678281.sentence: “We?” “Me and Pantalaimon. Us. But you, your dæmon en’t separate from you. It’s you. A part of you. You’re part of each other. En’t there anyone in your world like us? Are they all like you, with their dæmons all hidden away?”

678416.sentence: Will looked at the two of them, the skinny pale-eyed girl with her black rat dæmon now sitting in her arms, and felt profoundly alone.

680467.sentence: Lyra waited till she was sure he was asleep, and then took the dishes into the kitchen and ran them under the tap, rubbing hard with a cloth until they looked clean.

681033.sentence: She listened outside Will’s door and, hearing nothing, tiptoed into the other room and took out the alethiometer from under her pillow.

681189.sentence: She didn’t need to be close to Will to ask about him, but she wanted to look anyway, and she turned his door handle as quietly as she could before going in.

682399.sentence: A murderer was a worthy companion. She felt as safe with him as she’d felt with Iorek Byrnison, the armored bear.

682728.sentence: The witch Serafina Pekkala, who had rescued Lyra and the other children from the experimental station at Bolvangar and flown with her to the island of Svalbard, was deeply troubled.

682916.sentence: In the atmospheric disturbances that followed Lord Asriel’s escape from his exile on Svalbard, she and her companions were blown far from the island and many miles out over the frozen sea.

683155.sentence: Some of them managed to stay with the damaged balloon of Lee Scoresby, the Texan aeronaut, but Serafina herself was tossed high into the banks of fog that soon came rolling in from the gap that Lord Asriel’s experiment had torn in the sky.

683387.sentence: When she found herself able to control her flight once more, her first thought was of Lyra; for she knew nothing of the fight between the false bear-king and the true one, Iorek Byrnison, nor of what had happened to Lyra after that.

683537.sentence: So she began to search for her, flying through the cloudy gold-tinged air on her branch of cloud-pine, accompanied by her dæmon, Kaisa the snow goose.

683775.sentence: Serafina Pekkala knew from the unsettling tingle of the light on her skin that it came from another world.

683848.sentence: After some time had passed, Kaisa said, “Look! A witch’s dæmon, lost ...”

683994.sentence: Serafina Pekkala looked through the fog banks and saw a tern, circling and crying in the chasms of misty light. They wheeled and flew toward him.

684120.sentence: Seeing them come near, the tern darted up in alarm, but Serafina Pekkala signaled friendship, and he dropped down beside them.

684168.sentence: Serafina Pekkala said, “What clan are you from?”

684381.sentence: “The woman with the monkey dæmon, from Bolvangar.... Help me! Help us! I am so afraid!”

684719.sentence: “Quiet,”  said Kaisa, the goose dæmon. “Listen down below.”

684845.sentence: They glided lower, listening with keen ears, and Serafina Pekkala soon made out the beat of a gas engine, muffled by the fog.

684961.sentence: Kaisa said. “What are they doing?” “It’s a smaller engine than that,”

685141.sentence: said Serafina Pekkala, and as she spoke there came a new sound from a different direction: a low, brutal, shuddering blast, like some immense sea creature calling from the depths.

685882.sentence: Serafina Pekkala said to the lost dæmon:

686126.sentence: “What are you going to do? Will you look for my witch?” “Yes. But stay with Kaisa for now.”

686266.sentence: Serafina Pekkala flew down toward the launch, leaving the dæmons out of sight above, and alighted on the counter just behind the steersman.

687100.sentence: Serafina Pekkala flew up to the ship’s rail, and retreated to the shadows by the lifeboats.

687205.sentence: She could see no other witches, but they were probably patrolling the skies; Kaisa would know what to do.

687461.sentence: The figure was fur-swathed, hooded, anonymous; but as it reached the deck, a golden monkey dæmon swung himself lightly up on the rail and glared around, his black eyes radiating malevolence.

687517.sentence: Serafina caught her breath: the figure was Mrs. Coulter.

687688.sentence: “Lord Boreal—”  he began. But Mrs. Coulter interrupted:

687830.sentence: “Yes, Mrs. Coulter,”  was the reply, “but—” “I ordered them to wait,”  she snapped.

688052.sentence: Serafina Pekkala saw her face clearly in the yellow light: proud, passionate, and, to the witch, so young.

688244.sentence: “But a witch guided the launch in,”  said Mrs. Coulter. “Where has she gone?”

688342.sentence: Serafina shrank back; obviously the sailor in the launch hadn’t heard the latest state of things.

688577.sentence: The cleric looked around, bewildered, but Mrs. Coulter was too impatient, and after a cursory glance above and along the deck, she shook her head and hurried in with her dæmon through the open door that cast a yellow nimbus on the air.

688648.sentence: The man followed. Serafina Pekkala looked around to check her position.

689272.sentence: No one could see Serafina where she was; but if she wanted to see any more, she would have to leave her hiding place.

689619.sentence: It was fogged with condensation and impossible to see through, and Serafina could hear no voices, either. She withdrew to the shadows again.

691588.sentence: The meeting was being chaired by an elderly man in the robes of a Cardinal, and the rest of them seemed to be clerics of one sort or another, apart from Mrs. Coulter, who was the only woman present.

691712.sentence: Mrs. Coulter had thrown her furs over the back of the chair, and her cheeks were flushed in the heat of the ship’s interior.

691927.sentence: Serafina Pekkala looked around carefully and saw someone else in the room as well: a thin-faced man with a frog dæmon, seated to one side at a table laden with leather- bound books and loose piles of yellowed paper.

692395.sentence: Serafina looked back to the discussion at the table, because she heard the word witch.

692603.sentence: “I am wondering what Mrs. Coulter knows,”  said the Cardinal.

692739.sentence: “You will have to speak more plainly than that,”  said Mrs. Coulter icily.

692959.sentence: The Cardinal’s expression was full of meaning, but he said nothing.

693513.sentence: “It seems that there is a prophecy. It concerns the child, you see, Mrs. Coulter. All the signs have been fulfilled. The circumstances of her birth, to begin with. The gyptians know something about her too—they speak of her in terms of witch oil and marsh fire, uncanny, you see—hence her success in leading the gyptian men to Bolvangar. And then there’s her astonishing feat of deposing the bear-king Iofur Raknison—this is no ordinary child. Fra Pavel can tell us more, perhaps....”

693630.sentence: He glanced at the thin-faced man reading the alethiometer, who blinked, rubbed his eyes, and looked at Mrs. Coulter.

694378.sentence: “All the others have been acquired and destroyed, by order of the Magisterium. I learn from this instrument that the child was given hers by the Master of Jordan College, and that she learned to read it by herself, and that she can  use it without the books of readings. If it were possible to disbelieve the alethiometer, I would do so, because to use the instrument without the books is simply inconceivable to me. It takes decades of diligent study to reach any sort of understanding. She began to read it within a few weeks of acquiring it, and now she has an almost complete mastery. She is like no human Scholar I can imagine.”

694428.sentence: “Where is she now, Fra Pavel?”  said the Cardinal.

694507.sentence: “In the other world,”  said Fra Pavel. “It is already late.” “The witch knows!”

694751.sentence: “What is this prophecy?”  demanded Mrs. Coulter, who had been getting increasingly angry.

694903.sentence: The golden monkey glared around the table, and none of them could look him in the face.

694994.sentence: Only the Cardinal did not flinch. His dæmon, a macaw, lifted a foot and scratched her head.

695064.sentence: “The witch has hinted at something extraordinary,”  the Cardinal said.

695281.sentence: “I dare not believe what I think it means. If it’s true, it places on us the most terrible responsibility men and women have ever faced. But I ask you again, Mrs. Coulter—what do you know of the child and her father?”

695350.sentence: Mrs. Coulter had lost her flush. Her face was chalk-white with fury.

696297.sentence: “Please, Mrs. Coulter, the witch hasn’t spoken yet; we shall learn more from her. Cardinal Sturrock himself says that she’s only hinted at it.”

696359.sentence: “And suppose the witch doesn’t reveal it?”  Mrs. Coulter said.

696436.sentence: “What then? We guess, do we? We shiver and quail and guess?”  Fra Pavel said,

696812.sentence: “But the witch would tell us at once,”  said Mrs. Coulter. And she rose to her feet.

696905.sentence: Only the Cardinal and Fra Pavel remained seated.

696966.sentence: Serafina Pekkala stood back, fiercely holding herself unseen.

697055.sentence: The golden monkey was gnashing his teeth, and all his shimmering fur was standing on end.

697097.sentence: Mrs. Coulter swung him up to her shoulder.

697318.sentence: The men hastened to follow her, jostling and shoving past Serafina Pekkala, who had only time to stand quickly aside, her mind in a turmoil.

697455.sentence: The last to go was the Cardinal. Serafina took a few seconds to compose herself, because her agitation was beginning to make her visible.

697861.sentence: Mrs. Coulter stood over her. Serafina took up a position by the door, knowing that she could not stay unseen for long; this was too hard.

697914.sentence: “Tell us about the child, witch,”  said Mrs. Coulter.

698224.sentence: Mrs. Coulter said, and reached down to break one of the witch’s fingers. It snapped easily.

698454.sentence: The witch cried out, and for a clear second Serafina Pekkala became visible to everyone, and one or two of the clerics looked at her, puzzled and fearful; but then she controlled herself again, and they turned back to the torture.

698588.sentence: Mrs. Coulter was saying, “If you don’t answer I’ll break another finger, and then another. What do you know about the child? Tell me.”

698815.sentence: Serafina Pekkala could hardly hold herself back. Then came these words, in a shriek:

699137.sentence: “What is this name? Tell me!”  said Mrs. Coulter. “No ... no ...” “And how? Found out how?”

699510.sentence: Her voice gave out. Mrs. Coulter gave a little exclamation of impatience, and there came a loud slap, and a groan.

699638.sentence: Mrs. Coulter went on, and her voice was all bronze now, and ringing with passion.

699836.sentence: Serafina Pekkala moved closer, even among the tight throng of men around the witch, and none of them felt her presence at their very elbows.

700250.sentence: “She is the one who came before, and you have hated and feared her ever since! Well, now she has come again, and you failed to find her.... She was there on Svalbard—she was with Lord Asriel, and you lost her. She escaped, and she will be—”

700660.sentence: “Yambe-Akka! Come to me, come to me!”  No one but Serafina Pekkala understood.

700757.sentence: Yambe-Akka was the goddess who came to a witch when she was about to die. And Serafina was ready.

700900.sentence: She became visible at once and stepped forward smiling happily, because Yambe-Akka was merry and lighthearted and her visits were gifts of joy.

701033.sentence: The witch saw her and turned up her tear-stained face, and Serafina bent to kiss it and slid her knife gently into the witch’s heart.

701142.sentence: And now Serafina Pekkala would have to fight her way out.

701235.sentence: The men were still shocked, disbelieving, but Mrs. Coulter recovered her wits almost at once.

701354.sentence: “Seize her! Don’t let her go!”  she cried, but Serafina was already at the door, with an arrow nocked in her bowstring.

701474.sentence: She swung up the bow and loosed the arrow in less than a second, and the Cardinal fell choking and kicking to the floor.

702149.sentence: came a cry in Mrs. Coulter’s voice from behind, and at once three rifles fired, and the bullets struck metal and whined off into the fog as Serafina leaped on the branch and urged it up like one of her own arrows.

702348.sentence: “Where to?”  he said. “Away, Kaisa, away,”  she said.

702593.sentence: But there was one thing she knew for certain: there was an arrow in her quiver that would find its mark in Mrs. Coulter’s throat.

702741.sentence: They turned south, away from that troubling other-world gleam in the fog, and as they flew a question began to form more clearly in Serafina’s mind.

702868.sentence: What was Lord Asriel doing? Because all the events that had overturned the world had their origin in his mysterious activities.

703293.sentence: For knowledge about Lord Asriel, she had to go elsewhere.

703481.sentence: In the port of Trollesund, their consul Dr. Lanselius maintained his contact with the world of men and women, and Serafina Pekkala sped there through the fog to see what he could tell her.

703962.sentence: She tapped on the window, and Dr. Lanselius himself opened the door, a finger to his lips.

704532.sentence: “Not fully, I think. But they know she is important. As for that woman, I’m afraid of her, Dr. Lanselius. I shall kill her, I think, but still I’m afraid of her.”

704635.sentence: And Serafina listened as he told her of the rumors that had swept the town.

705300.sentence: “They say that the Magisterium is assembling the greatest army ever known, and this is an advance party. And there are unpleasant rumors about some of the soldiers, Serafina Pekkala. I’ve heard about Bolvangar, and what they were doing there—cutting children’s dæmons away, the most evil work I’ve ever heard of. Well, it seems there is a regiment of warriors who have been treated in the same way. Do you know the word  zombi? They fear nothing, because they’re mindless. There are some in this town now. The authorities keep them hidden, but word gets out, and the townspeople are terrified of them.”

705389.sentence: “What of the other witch clans?”  said Serafina Pekkala. “What news do you have of them?”

705531.sentence: “Most have gone back to their homelands. All the witches are waiting, Serafina Pekkala, with fear in their hearts, for what will happen next.”

705658.sentence: “And what do you hear of the Church?” “They’re in complete confusion. You see, they don’t know what Lord Asriel intends to do.”

705768.sentence: “and I can’t imagine what it might be. What do you think he’s intending, Dr. Lanselius?”

706382.sentence: “but scholarship is not his ruling passion. Nor is statesmanship. I met him once, and I thought he had an ardent and powerful nature, but not a despotic one. I don’t think he wants to rule.... I don’t know, Serafina Pekkala. I suppose his servant might be able to tell you. He is a man called Thorold, and he was imprisoned with Lord Asriel in the house on Svalbard. It might be worth a visit there to see if he can tell you anything; but, of course, he might have gone into the other world with his master.”

706550.sentence: She said farewell to the consul and flew up through the gathering dark to join Kaisa in the clouds.

706639.sentence: Serafina’s journey to the north was made harder by the confusion in the world around her.

707438.sentence: In all this turmoil, where sudden shafts of uncanny brilliance lanced down through rents in towers of fog and then vanished as quickly, where herds of muskox were seized by the urge to gallop south and then wheeled immediately to the west or the north again, where tight-knit skeins of geese disintegrated into a honking chaos as the magnetic fields they flew by wavered and snapped this way and that, Serafina Pekkala sat on her cloud-pine and flew north, to the house on the headland in the wastes of Svalbard.

707523.sentence: There she found Lord Asriel’s servant, Thorold, fighting off a group of cliff-ghasts.

708379.sentence: Serafina flew down to the courtyard and alighted on the trampled, blood-sprinkled snow.

708587.sentence: “I am a friend of Lyra’s,”  she said.

708759.sentence: “In another world. I’m concerned for her safety. And I need to know what Lord Asriel is doing.”

709021.sentence: Kaisa glided through the skies above, keeping watch, while Thorold brewed some coffee and Serafina told him of her involvement with Lyra.

709357.sentence: “I’d see her every year or so when his lordship visited his college. I was fond of her, mind—you couldn’t help it. But what her place was in the wider scheme of things, I don’t know.” “What was Lord Asriel planning to do?”

709680.sentence: “You don’t think he told me, do you, Serafina Pekkala? I’m his manservant, that’s all. I clean his clothes and cook his meals and keep his house tidy. I may have learned a thing or two in the years I been with his lordship, but only by picking ’em up accidental. He wouldn’t confide in me any more than in his shaving mug.”

709907.sentence: Thorold was an elderly man, but he was healthy and vigorous, and he felt flattered by the attention of this young witch and her beauty, as any man would.

710534.sentence: “Yes, that’s true.” “But you know about our God? The God of the Church, the one they call the Authority?” “Yes, I do.”

710943.sentence: “Well, Lord Asriel has never found hisself at ease with the doctrines of the Church, so to speak. I’ve seen a spasm of disgust cross his face when they talk of the sacraments, and atonement, and redemption, and suchlike. It’s death among our people, Serafina Pekkala, to challenge the Church, but Lord Asriel’s been nursing a rebellion in his heart for as long as I’ve served him, that’s one thing I do know.”

711671.sentence: “that wouldn’t stop my master. Now this might sound strange to you, Serafina Pekkala, but I know the man better than any wife could know him, better than a mother. He’s been my master and my study for nigh on forty years. I can’t follow him to the height of his thought any more than I can fly, but I can see where he’s a-heading even if I can’t go after him. No, it’s my belief he turned away from a rebellion against the Church not because the Church was too strong, but because it was too weak to be worth the fighting.”

712080.sentence: “So ... what is he doing?” “I think he’s a-waging a higher war than that. I think he’s aiming a rebellion against the highest power of all. He’s gone a-searching for the dwelling place of the Authority Himself, and he’s a-going to destroy Him. That’s what I think. It shakes my heart to voice it, ma’am. I hardly dare think of it. But I can’t put together any other story that makes sense of what he’s doing.”

712187.sentence: Serafina sat quiet for a few moments, absorbing what Thorold had said. Before she could speak, he went on:

712707.sentence: “ ’Course, anyone setting out to do a grand thing like that would be the target of the Church’s anger. Goes without saying. It’d be the most gigantic blasphemy, that’s what they’d say. They’d have him before the Consistorial Court and sentenced to death before you could blink. I’ve never spoke of it before and I shan’t again; I’d be afraid to speak it aloud to you if you weren’t a witch and beyond the power of the Church; but that makes sense, and nothing else does. He’s a-going to find the Authority and kill Him.”

713023.sentence: “Lord Asriel’s life has been filled with things that were impossible. I wouldn’t like to say there was anything he couldn’t do. But on the face of it, Serafina Pekkala, yes, he’s stark mad. If angels couldn’t do it, how can a man dare to think about it?” “Angels? What are angels?”

713828.sentence: “Beings of pure spirit, the Church says. The Church teaches that some of the angels rebelled before the world was created, and got flung out of heaven and into hell. They failed, you see, that’s the point. They couldn’t do it. And they had the power of angels. Lord Asriel is just a man, with human power, no more than that. But his ambition is limitless. He dares to do what men and women don’t even dare to think. And look what he’s done already: he’s torn open the sky, he’s opened the way to another world. Who else has ever done that? Who else could think of it? So with one part of me, Serafina Pekkala, I say he’s mad, wicked, deranged. Yet with another part I think, he’s Lord Asriel, he’s not like other men. Maybe ... if it was ever going to be possible, it’d be done by him and by no one else.”

714017.sentence: “And what will you do, Thorold?” “I’ll stay here and wait. I’ll guard this house till he comes back and tells me different, or till I die. And now I might ask you the same question, ma’am.”

714175.sentence: “It might be that I have to pass this way again, Thorold. I’m glad to know that you will still be here.”

714260.sentence: She refused Thorold’s offer of food, and said good-bye.

714763.sentence: These were human affairs she was inquiring into, this was a human matter; Lord Asriel’s god was not hers.

714954.sentence: “We must talk to our sisters, Kaisa. These events are too big for us alone.”

715126.sentence: In the forested caves beside the lake they found the others of their clan, and Lee Scoresby, too.

715489.sentence: “None, Mr. Scoresby. Will you join our council tonight and help us discuss what to do?”

716411.sentence: Serafina Pekkala sat in the center, the crown of little scarlet flowers nestling among her fair hair.

716530.sentence: On her left sat Lee Scoresby, and on her right, a visitor: the queen of the Latvian witches, whose name was Ruta Skadi.

716590.sentence: She had arrived only an hour before, to Serafina’s surprise.

716754.sentence: Serafina had thought Mrs. Coulter beautiful, for a short-life; but Ruta Skadi was as lovely as Mrs. Coulter, with an extra dimension of the mysterious, the uncanny.

716910.sentence: She was vivid and passionate, with large black eyes; it was said that Lord Asriel himself had been her lover.

717255.sentence: Serafina’s dæmon, Kaisa, had learned  from Ruta Skadi’s dæmon that she had killed the tigers herself in order to punish the Tartar tribe who worshiped them, because the tribesmen had failed to do her honor when she had visited their territory.

717553.sentence: Such was Ruta Skadi: beautiful, proud, and pitiless.

717691.sentence: Serafina was not sure why she had come, but made the queen welcome, and etiquette demanded that Ruta Skadi should sit on Serafina’s right.

717745.sentence: When they were all assembled, Serafina began to speak.

718380.sentence: “Sisters! You know why we have come together: we must decide what to do about these new events. The universe is broken wide, and Lord Asriel has opened the way from this world to another. Should we concern ourselves with it, or live our lives as we have done until now, looking after our own affairs? Then there is the matter of the child Lyra Belacqua, now called Lyra Silvertongue by King Iorek Byrnison. She chose the right cloud-pine spray at the house of Dr. Lanselius: she is the child we have always expected, and now she has vanished. “We have two guests, who will tell us their thoughts. First we shall hear Queen Ruta Skadi.”

718551.sentence: Ruta Skadi stood. Her white arms gleamed in the firelight; her eyes glittered so brightly that even the farthest witch could see the play of expression on her vivid face.

720084.sentence: “let me tell you what is happening, and who it is that we must fight. For there is a war coming. I don’t know who will join with us, but I know whom we must fight. It is the Magisterium, the Church. For all its history—and that’s not long by our lives, but it’s many, many of theirs—it’s tried to suppress and control every natural impulse. And when it can’t control them, it cuts them out. Some of you have seen what they did at Bolvangar. And that was horrible, but it is not the only such place, not the only such practice. Sisters, you know only the north; I have traveled in the south lands. There are churches there, believe me, that cut their children too, as the people of Bolvangar did—not in the same way, but just as horribly. They cut their sexual organs, yes, both boys and girls; they cut them with knives so that they shan’t feel. That is what the Church does, and every church is the same: control, destroy, obliterate every good feeling. So if a war comes, and the Church is on one side of it, we must be on the other, no matter what strange allies we find ourselves bound to. “What I propose is that our clans join together and go north to explore this new world, and see what we can discover there. If the child is not to be found in our world, it’s because she will have gone after Lord Asriel already. And Lord Asriel is the key to this, believe me. He was my lover once, and I would willingly join forces with him, because he hates the Church and all it does. “That is what I have to say.”

720162.sentence: Ruta Skadi spoke passionately, and Serafina admired her power and her beauty.

720227.sentence: When the Latvian queen sat down, Serafina turned to Lee Scoresby.

722268.sentence: “I have to thank you all first for the kindness you’ve shown to me, and the help you extended to an aeronaut battered by winds that came from another world. I won’t trespass long on your patience. “When I was traveling north to Bolvangar with the gyptians, the child Lyra told me about something that happened in the college she used to live in, back in Oxford. Lord Asriel had shown the other scholars the severed head of a man called Stanislaus Grumman, and that kinda persuaded them to give him some money to come north and find out what had happened. “Now, the child was so sure of what she’d seen that I didn’t like to question her too much. But what she said made a kind of memory come to my mind, except that I couldn’t reach it clearly. I knew something about this Dr. Grumman. And it was only on the flight here from Svalbard that I remembered what it was. It was an old hunter from Tungusk who told me. It seems that Grumman knew the whereabouts of some kind of object that gives protection to whoever holds it. I don’t want to belittle the magic that you witches can command, but this thing, whatever it is, has a kind of power that outclasses anything I’ve ever heard of. “And I thought I might postpone my retirement to Texas because of my concern for that child, and search for Dr. Grumman. You see, I don’t think he’s dead. I think Lord Asriel was fooling those scholars. “So I’m going to Nova Zembla, where I last heard of him alive, and I’m going to search for him. I cain’t see the future, but I can see the present clear enough. And I’m with you in this war, for what my bullets are worth. But that’s the task I’m going to take on, ma’am,”

A big splinter of wood off a plank didn’t, but a wooden ruler did. And a carved wooden statuette had more.... I’m talking about elementary particles here, for goodness’ sake. Little minute lumps of scarcely anything. They knew what these objects were. Anything that was associated with human workmanship and human thought was surrounded by Shadows.... “And then Oliver—Dr. Payne—got some fossil skulls from a friend at the museum and tested them to see how far back in time the effect went. The Master of Jordan College gave it me. In my Oxford there’s a Jordan College, but there en’t one here. I looked. And I found out how to read the alethiometer by myself. I got a way of making my mind go blank, and I just see what the pictures mean straightaway. Just like you said about ... doubts and mysteries and that. So when I looked at the Cave, I done the same thing, and it works just the same way, so my Dust and your Shadows are the same, too. So ...”

793516.sentence: Dr. Malone was fully awake now. Lyra picked up the alethiometer and folded its velvet cloth over it, like a mother protecting her child, before putting it back in her rucksack.

794000.sentence: Dr. Malone rubbed her face and turned her cheeks red again.

794298.sentence: “You got to think about it,”  said Lyra severely.

794624.sentence: “ ’Cause you got tonight, then,”  said Lyra.

795342.sentence: Dr. Malone gave her a tissue to wipe off the gel, and folded up the wires.

795504.sentence: “Are you going to make it do words?”  Lyra said, gathering up her rucksack.

795596.sentence: “It’s about as much use as completing the funding application, I daresay,”  said Dr. Malone.

795755.sentence: Lyra narrowed her eyes. Was this a trap?

795881.sentence: “Yes. Of course. You will come?” “Yes,”  said Lyra.

796211.sentence: “Who was the other one?”  said Will, on his guard at once.

796655.sentence: “Well,”  said Will, trying to keep calm,

798443.sentence: “Yes,”  said Will. “Thank you. Umm ... that journalist,”  he went on, stopping at the door.

798548.sentence: “The explorer type. A man called Parry.”

798688.sentence: Will couldn’t think of a plausible reason.

798855.sentence: “Right, thanks,”  Will said, and turned to go.

799014.sentence: Will saw him reach for the phone, and left the building quickly. He found he was shaking.

799319.sentence: He wasn’t the one Will had knocked down the stairs: he was the one who’d appeared at the door of the living room as Will ran down and jumped over the body.

799484.sentence: Will went in, holding his clipboard as if he were working, and sat down in a gallery hung with paintings.

800061.sentence: People came and went, looking at the paintings, talking in quiet voices, ignoring him; a gallery attendant stood in the doorway for a few minutes, hands behind his back, and then slowly moved away; and Will wrestled with the horror of what he’d done, and didn’t move a muscle.

801160.sentence: They were leaving, because the attendant was telling them that the museum would close in ten minutes. Will gathered himself and left.

801570.sentence: Will turned aside at once, casually, and looked in the window of the jeweler’s shop beside him.

801738.sentence: As soon as he’d gone in, Will moved away, his heart thudding again.

801827.sentence: There wasn’t anywhere safe. He drifted toward the university library and waited for Lyra.

802144.sentence: “I found my Scholar! She’s called Dr. Malone. And she’s got an engine that can see Dust, and she’s going to make it talk—”

802573.sentence: Before they reached the bench, Lyra was on her feet and speaking to them.

802792.sentence: The policeman looked at Will, and Will, containing his anger, shrugged as if to say,

802996.sentence: said Lyra, and pretended to listen carefully as the woman gave her instructions.

803065.sentence: Will got up and said, “Thanks,”  and he and Lyra moved away together.

803909.sentence: She finally became aware of Will’s feelings and said, “What’s the matter?”

804997.sentence: She was an aristocrat. She was Lyra.

805294.sentence: When she said this, though, Will stopped altogether.

806354.sentence: Will looked around carefully, but there was no one near to see; a group of tourists looked up at the domed building, an ice cream vendor wheeled his cart along the pavement, but their attention was elsewhere.

806415.sentence: Lyra blinked and sighed, as if she were waking after a sleep.

807714.sentence: Will put his head in his hands with weariness.

807835.sentence: “That’s all right. I trust you.”  Will nodded grimly.

808127.sentence: Lyra wasn’t usually so perceptive, but something in his manner made her think: He’s afraid, but he’s mastering his fear, like Iorek Byrnison said we had to do; like I did by the fish house at the frozen lake.

808828.sentence: “I’m hungry,”  Lyra said. Then he said,

809144.sentence: Will paid for both of them to get in, and bought hot dogs and popcorn and Coke, and they carried the food inside and sat down just as the film was beginning.

809256.sentence: Lyra was entranced. She had seen projected photograms, but nothing in her world had prepared her for the cinema.

809527.sentence: Will closed his eyes at once and went to sleep.

809682.sentence: His watch showed a quarter past eight. Lyra came away reluctantly.

809926.sentence: Will couldn’t even remember what the film had been.

810211.sentence: Lyra settled down with her feet on the seat, hugging her knees, and Will let his mind go blank.

810404.sentence: Lyra was hungry again, so they bought hamburgers from a cart and ate them as they walked along, something else new to her.

810970.sentence: “There’s so many ways this place is different. The traffic, for one. I don’t like it. I like the cinema, though, and hamburgers. I like them a lot. And that Scholar, Dr. Malone, she’s going to make that engine use words. I just know she is. I’ll go back there tomorrow and see how she’s getting on. I bet I could help her. I could probably get the Scholars to give her the money she wants, too. You know how my father did it? Lord Asriel? He played a trick on them....”

811168.sentence: As they walked up the Banbury Road, she told him about the night she hid in the wardrobe and watched Lord Asriel show the Jordan Scholars the severed head of Stanislaus Grumman in the vacuum flask.

811408.sentence: And since Will was such a good audience, she went on and told him the rest of her story, from the time she escaped from Mrs. Coulter’s flat to the horrible moment when she realized she’d led Roger to his death on the icy cliffs of Svalbard.

811470.sentence: Will listened without comment, but attentively, with sympathy.

811954.sentence: And there was the window. Will felt himself smiling. It was going to be all right.

812168.sentence: And a moment later he was on the grass under the palm trees, and a second or two afterward Lyra followed. They felt as if they were home again.

812355.sentence: Lyra stretched and yawned, and Will felt a great weight lift off his shoulders.

812584.sentence: And then Lyra gripped his arm. In the same second he heard what had made her do it.

812783.sentence: Will set off at once toward the sound, and Lyra followed behind as he plunged down a narrow alley shadowed from the moonlight.

813235.sentence: At first Lyra thought it was another child, but coming from inside the semicircle was a horrible high wailing that wasn’t human at all.

813357.sentence: Will ran up to the children and pulled the first one back.

813556.sentence: As he turned Lyra saw the wild white rims around his pupils, and then the other children realized what was happening and stopped to look.

813702.sentence: Angelica and her little brother were there too, stones in hand, and all the children’s eyes glittered fiercely in the moonlight. They fell silent.

813864.sentence: Only the high wailing continued, and then both Will and Lyra saw what it was: a tabby cat, cowering against the wall of the tower, its ear torn and its tail bent.

813974.sentence: It was the cat Will had seen in Sunderland Avenue, the one like Moxie, the one that had led him to the window.

814191.sentence: Will was already kneeling by the cat. And then she was in his arms.

814343.sentence: She fled to his breast and he cradled her close and stood to face the children, and Lyra thought for a crazy second that his dæmon had appeared at last.

814581.sentence: They stood trembling at Will’s anger, breathing heavily, clutching their sticks and their stones, and they couldn’t speak. But then Angelica’s voice came clearly:

814940.sentence: The boy in the striped T-shirt whom Will had thrown down was trembling to fight, and if it hadn’t been for the cat in Will’s arms, he would have flown at Will with fists and teeth and feet, and Will would have gladly joined battle.

815605.sentence: For a moment Will thought their hatred would overcome their fear, and he was preparing to put the cat down and fight, but then came a low thunderous growl from behind the children, and they turned to see Lyra standing with her hand on the shoulders of a great spotted leopard whose teeth shone white as he snarled.

815672.sentence: Even Will, who recognized Pantalaimon, was frightened for a second.

815833.sentence: But before they left, Lyra looked up at the tower.

816025.sentence: A growl from Pantalaimon prompted her, and just briefly she saw someone there on the very top, looking down over the battlemented rim, and not a child either, but a young man, with curly hair.

816190.sentence: Will had found a tin of condensed milk, and the cat had lapped it hungrily and then begun to lick her wounds.

816420.sentence: Pantalaimon had become cat-formed out of curiosity, and at first the tabby cat had bristled with suspicion, but she soon realized that whatever Pantalaimon was, he was  neither a true cat nor a threat, and proceeded to ignore him.

816472.sentence: Lyra watched Will tending this one with fascination.

816714.sentence: “I think her tail’s broken,”  Will said.

817619.sentence: A little later, when the cat had curled up to sleep, Will took a cup of coffee and the green leather writing case, and sat on the balcony.

818361.sentence: Fairbanks, Alaska Wednesday, 19 June 1985 My darling—the usual mixture of efficiency and chaos—all the stores are here but the physicist, a genial dimwit called Nelson, hasn’t made any arrangements for carrying his damn balloons up into the mountains—having to twiddle our thumbs while he scrabbles around for transport.

818462.sentence: But it means I had a chance to talk to an old boy I met last time, a gold miner called Jake Petersen.

819089.sentence: However, old Jake did have a map of the area, and he’d marked on it where his pal had told him the thing was.

819446.sentence: The archaeologists are a decent crew, keen to get to work, containing their impatience with Nelson and his balloons.

819572.sentence: My fondest love to you both. Johnny.

819784.sentence: Umiat, Alaska Saturday, 22 June 1985 My darling—so much for what did I call him, a genial dimwit—the physicist Nelson is nothing of the sort, and if I’m not mistaken he’s actually looking for the anomaly himself.

820911.sentence: But I’m right, Elaine—he’s looking for it too.

821012.sentence: The question is, do I tell him or not? Got to work out what his game is. Fondest love to both—Johnny.

821783.sentence: Talking of which, the physicist Nelson is my closest buddy now—kids me along, drops hints to imply that he knows that I know that he knows, etc.

821913.sentence: And I pretend to be bluff Major Parry, stout fellow in a crisis but not too much between the ears, what. But I know he’s after it.

822409.sentence: If I bump into Nelson wandering about on Lookout Ridge, I’ll play it by ear.

822486.sentence: I met Jake Petersen’s pal the Eskimo, Matt Kigalik.

822563.sentence: Jake had told me where to find him, but I hadn’t dared to hope he’d be there.

823342.sentence: It’s on the north side of a small creek fifty paces or so to the west of a tall rock shaped like a standing bear, and the position Jake gave me is not quite right—it’s nearer 12′ N than 11.

823495.sentence: I love you forever—kiss the boy for me —Johnny. Will found his head ringing.

823678.sentence: He, too, had found a window—he even used the same word for it! So Will must be on the right track.

823821.sentence: So it was dangerous, too. Will had been just a baby when that letter was written.

824478.sentence: But he felt deeply happy that he had something so important to share with his father; that John Parry and his son Will had each, separately, discovered this extraordinary thing.

824589.sentence: When they met, they could talk about it, and his father would be proud that Will had followed in his footsteps.

825050.sentence: Sam Cansino, an old acquaintance and a Texan like Lee Scoresby, sat in the naphtha-laden, smoky bar of the Samirsky Hotel and tossed back a shot glass of bitingly cold vodka.

825170.sentence: He nudged the plate of pickled fish and black bread toward Lee, who took a mouthful and nodded for Sam to tell him more.

825838.sentence: “You don’t say,”  said Lee Scoresby, tipping more vodka into Sam’s glass.

825943.sentence: His dæmon, Hester, crouched at his elbow on the bar, eyes half-closed as usual, ears flat along her back.

826143.sentence: Lee had arrived that afternoon, borne to Nova Zembla by the wind the witches had called up, and once he’d stowed his equipment he’d made straight for the Samirsky Hotel, near the fish-packing station.

826431.sentence: This was a place where many Arctic drifters stopped to exchange news or look for employment or leave messages for one another, and Lee Scoresby had spent several days there in the past, waiting for a contract or a passenger or a fair wind, so there was nothing unusual in his conduct now.

827157.sentence: Altogether it was a bad time to work, which was why the bar of the Samirsky Hotel was full. “Did you say Grumman?”

827510.sentence: “Well, how about that,”  said Lee Scoresby.

827945.sentence: “I remember it now. I’ve flown over it. And Grumman had his skull drilled, you say? Why was that?”

828252.sentence: “Ah, that accounts for the way his team was obeying him,”  said Sam Cansino.

829030.sentence: “Is that so?”  said Lee, thinking of the beauty of Serafina Pekkala.

829340.sentence: “He might have had a reason,”  said Lee.

829479.sentence: “Maybe faithful to another woman,”  Lee guessed.

829833.sentence: “He didn’t have it himself, but he knew where it was. There was a man who tried to make him tell, but Grumman killed him.”

830153.sentence: “You’re talking about Stan Grumman? His dæmon was an osprey. A fish eagle.”

830196.sentence: “What happened to him?”  said Lee Scoresby.

830379.sentence: “Oh, he got mixed up in the Skraeling wars over to Beringland. Last I heard he’d been shot,”  said the seal hunter. “Killed outright.” “I heard they beheaded him,”  said Lee Scoresby.

830642.sentence: “and I know, because I heard it from an Inuit who was with him. Seems that they were camped out on Sakhalin somewhere and there was an avalanche. Grumman was buried under a hundred tons of rock. This Inuit saw it happen.”

830716.sentence: “What I can’t understand,”  said Lee Scoresby, offering the bottle around,

830909.sentence: “is what the man was doing. Was he prospecting for rock oil, maybe? Or was he a military man? Or was it something philosophical? You said something about measurements, Sam. What would that be?”

831376.sentence: “What d’you want to know for, anyway, Lee?”  said Sam Cansino. “He owes me some money,”  said Lee Scoresby.

832398.sentence: “Ain’t never seen a fog like this,”  grumbled Sam Cansino.

832530.sentence: “Reckon it’s set in for a month, maybe more. But you’re out of luck if you want money from Stanislaus Grumman, Lee; the man’s dead.”

832666.sentence: “I just remembered what they called him during the drilling. It sounded like Jopari.”

832729.sentence: “Jopari? That’s no kind of name I’ve ever heard of,”  said Lee.

833052.sentence: The observatory was some distance to the north, and Lee Scoresby hired a dog sledge and driver.

833273.sentence: It wasn’t easy to find someone willing to risk the journey in the fog, but Lee was persuasive, or his money was; and eventually an old Tartar from the Ob region  agreed to take him there, after a lengthy bout of haggling.

833594.sentence: Lee, who carried his compass everywhere, had realized already that the earth’s magnetic field was as disturbed as everything else.

834217.sentence: “What’s going to happen, Umaq?” “Same thing as before. Make all same again. But only after big trouble, big war. Spirit war.”

834653.sentence: “Yeah, I want to go back when I’ve finished, Umaq. You make yourself a fire, my friend, and sit and rest a spell. I’ll be three, four hours maybe.”

834859.sentence: Lee Scoresby set off, with Hester tucked into the breast of his coat, and after half an hour’s stiff climb found a clump of buildings suddenly above him as if they’d just been placed there by a giant hand.

835431.sentence: A few minutes after he arrived, Lee was talking to a group of astronomers eager to learn what news he could bring them, for there are few natural philosophers as frustrated as astronomers in a fog.

835558.sentence: He told them about everything he’d seen, and once that topic had been thoroughly dealt with, he asked about Stanislaus Grumman.

835702.sentence: “Grumman? Yes, I’ll tell you something about him,”  said the Director.

836642.sentence: Lee Scoresby sensed that the little community was glad to have a visitor, if only because he introduced a change of conversation.

837418.sentence: “That’s the point. According to Grumman, the earth’s magnetic field changed dramatically at various times in the past, and the earth’s axis actually moved, too, so that temperate areas became icebound.”

837807.sentence: “How long had you known Grumman, gentlemen?”

837867.sentence: Lee Scoresby asked. “Well, let me see,”  said the Director.

838328.sentence: They talked on for a while, contributing reminiscences and offering suggestions as to what might have become of Grumman, though most of them thought he was probably dead.

838420.sentence: While the Pole went to brew some more coffee, Lee’s hare dæmon, Hester, said to him quietly:

838490.sentence: “Check out the Skraeling, Lee.”  The Skraeling had spoken very little.

838702.sentence: Lee had thought he was naturally taciturn, but prompted by Hester, he casually glanced across during the next break in the conversation to see the man’s dæmon, a snowy owl, glaring at him with bright orange eyes.

838873.sentence: Well, that was what owls looked like, and they did stare; but Hester was right, and there was a hostility and suspicion in the dæmon that the man’s face showed nothing of.

838979.sentence: And then Lee saw something else: the Skraeling was wearing a ring with the Church’s symbol engraved on it.

839305.sentence: So, realizing this, and remembering something he’d heard Lyra say, Lee asked:

839397.sentence: “Tell me, gentlemen—do you happen to know if Grumman ever looked into the question of Dust?”

839715.sentence: Lee knew that Hester would remain inscrutable, with her eyes half-closed and her ears flat along her back, and he put on a cheerful innocence as he looked from face to face.

839914.sentence: The Skraeling said, “Where did you hear mention of this subject, Mr. Scoresby?”

839986.sentence: “From a passenger I flew across the sea a while back,”  Lee said easily.

840314.sentence: “They never said what it was, but from the way it was mentioned it seemed like the kind of thing Dr. Grumman might have inquired into. I took it to be some kind of celestial thing, like the aurora. But it puzzled me, because as an aeronaut I know the skies pretty well, and I’d never come across this stuff. What is it, anyhow?”

840517.sentence: Presently Lee decided it was time to leave; he had learned no more, and he didn’t want to keep Umaq waiting.

840794.sentence: And when they were only ten minutes down the path, something swept past his head in the fog and dived at Hester.

840920.sentence: It was the Skraeling’s owl dæmon. But Hester sensed her coming and flattened herself in time, and the owl’s claws just missed.

840995.sentence: Hester could fight; her claws were sharp, too, and she was tough and brave.

841090.sentence: Lee knew that the Skraeling himself must be close by, and reached for the revolver at his belt.

841191.sentence: “Behind you, Lee,”  Hester said, and he whipped around, diving, as an arrow hissed over his shoulder.

841499.sentence: Lee Scoresby cocked his pistol and held it to the man’s head.

841865.sentence: “Too late to stop. I have already sent a messenger bird. The Magisterium will know of your inquiries, and they will be glad to know about Grumman—” “What about him?”

842121.sentence: “The fact that others are looking for him. It confirms what we thought. And that  others know of Dust. You are an enemy of the Church, Lee Scoresby. By their fruits shall ye know them. By their questions shall ye see the serpent gnawing at their heart....”

842397.sentence: There was a gathering red stain in the snow around the Skraeling; even in the fog-thick dimness, Lee could see that the man was going to die.

842904.sentence: The Skraeling’s soul was gone. Lee had once seen a painting in which a saint of the Church was shown being attacked by assassins.

843213.sentence: Lee dropped him in distaste. Hester clicked her tongue.

843629.sentence: Lee saw the sense, and took the ring off the dead man’s finger.

843912.sentence: Lee had never enjoyed violence, and he hated killing, although he’d had to do it three times before.

843954.sentence: “No sense in thinking that,”  said Hester.

844069.sentence: “He didn’t give us a choice, and we didn’t shoot to kill. Damn it, Lee, he wanted to die. These people are insane.”

844292.sentence: “Tell me, Umaq,”  Lee said as they set off back to the fish-packing station,

844332.sentence: “you ever hear of a man called Grumman?”

844428.sentence: “Oh, sure,”  said the driver. “Everybody know Dr. Grumman.” “Did you know he had a Tartar name?”

844506.sentence: “Not Tartar. You mean Jopari? Not Tartar.” “What happened to him? Is he dead?”

845130.sentence: But when they returned to the station, Lee went at once to the docks and looked for a ship that could give him passage to the mouth of the Yenisei.

845339.sentence: The Latvian queen, Ruta Skadi, flew with Serafina Pekkala’s company for many days and nights, through fog and whirlwind, over regions devastated by flood or landslide.

846207.sentence: “Are they alive, do you think, Serafina Pekkala?”

846335.sentence: said Ruta Skadi as the witches circled high above a group of the things that stood motionless at the edge of a tract of forest.

846394.sentence: “Alive or dead, they’re full of malice,”  Serafina replied.

847126.sentence: Serafina caught her breath: these people had no dæmons, and yet they seemed alive.

847665.sentence: Serafina was shocked to see the leading rider turn tail at once and gallop away, without staying to help his comrades, and the second rider did the same, escaping as fast as he could in another direction.

847766.sentence: “Fly lower and watch, sisters,”  Serafina told her companions. “But don’t interfere till I  command.”

848272.sentence: One old woman seated on a cart held two little children on her lap, and Ruta Skadi was angered by her cowardice: because she tried to hide behind them, and thrust them out toward the Specter that approached her, as if offering them up to save her own life.

848655.sentence: The old woman in the cart was soon enveloped in a transparent shimmer that moved busily, working and feeding in some invisible way that made Ruta Skadi sick to watch.

848812.sentence: Fascinated and stunned, Serafina Pekkala flew down even closer.

849154.sentence: What was happening to him? Serafina hovered above the water a few feet away, gazing horrified.

849848.sentence: That was too much for Serafina. She swooped lower and plucked the child from the water, and as she did so, Ruta Skadi cried out: “Be careful, sister! Behind you—”

850014.sentence: And Serafina felt just for a moment a hideous dullness at the edge of her heart, and reached out and up for Ruta Skadi’s hand, which pulled her away from the danger.

850210.sentence: They flew higher, the child screaming and clinging to her waist with sharp fingers, and Serafina saw the Specter behind her, a drift of mist swirling on the water, casting about for its lost prey.

850279.sentence: Ruta Skadi shot an arrow into the heart of it, with no effect at all.

850412.sentence: Serafina put the child down on the riverbank, seeing that it was in no danger from the Specters, and they retreated to the air again.

850957.sentence: As the last of the Specters drifted away, sated, Serafina flew down and alighted in front of a woman sitting on the grass, a strong, healthy- looking woman whose cheeks were red and whose fair hair was glossy.

851064.sentence: “Woman?”  said Serafina. There was no response. “Can you hear me? Can you see me?”  She shook her shoulder.

851262.sentence: Her eyes were vacant, and when Serafina pinched the skin of her forearm, she merely looked down slowly and then away again.

851770.sentence: “We’ll speak to him,”  said Serafina, and sprang into the air.

852119.sentence: As he saw the witches approach, he unslung the rifle from his back and kicked the horse forward onto the grass, where he could wheel and fire and face them in the open; but Serafina Pekkala alighted slowly and held her bow out before laying it on the ground in front of her.

852350.sentence: The man lowered the rifle from his shoulder and waited, looking from Serafina to the other witches, and up to their dæmons too, who circled in the skies above.

852601.sentence: Serafina, coming closer, saw sorrow in his face as well, and strength.

852849.sentence: “My name is Serafina Pekkala. I am the queen of the witches of Lake Enara, which is in another world. What is your name?”

852919.sentence: “Joachim Lorenz. Witches, you say? Do you treat with the devil, then?”

853480.sentence: “There’s no defense against them,”  said Joachim Lorenz.

853938.sentence: Ruta Skadi was looking around. She noticed the other rider moving back toward the wagons, and saw that it was, indeed, a woman.

854040.sentence: The children were running to meet her. “But tell me what you’re looking for,”  Joachim Lorenz went on.

854170.sentence: “We’re looking for a child,”  said Serafina,

854357.sentence: “a young girl from our world. Her name is Lyra Belacqua, called Lyra Silvertongue. But where she might be, in a whole world, we can’t guess. You haven’t seen a strange child, on her own?”

854811.sentence: The other rider had dismounted now and was comforting some of the children. Serafina followed his gaze and said,

855779.sentence: Serafina picked up the little boy who’d fallen in the river, and who was crying out for his daddy, reaching back over Serafina’s shoulder to the silent figure still standing in the water, indifferent.

855820.sentence: Serafina felt his tears on her bare skin.

856393.sentence: Later, as the embers of a fire glowed in a circle of ashy rocks and the great hills lay calm under the moon, Joachim Lorenz told Serafina and Ruta Skadi about the history of his world.

858144.sentence: “Who are these philosophers?”  said Serafina. “And where is this tower you speak of?”

859137.sentence: “Why don’t the Specters harm children?”  asked Ruta Skadi.

860516.sentence: Serafina told him truthfully as much as she knew.

861147.sentence: “You want to know about angels?”  said Joachim Lorenz.

863596.sentence: Though Joachim Lorenz looked anything but hopeful as he stared into the flames.

863739.sentence: The flickering light played over his face, but there was no play of expression in his strong features; he looked grim and sad. Ruta Skadi said,

864486.sentence: “Sir,”  said Serafina, “did you ever hear of Dust?”

864912.sentence: Ruta Skadi stood up. “Sister, it’s time I parted from you,”  she said to Serafina.

865101.sentence: “I’m going up to speak to these angels, whatever they may be. If they’re going to Lord Asriel, I’ll go with them. If not, I’ll search on by myself. Thank you for your company, and go well.”

865181.sentence: They kissed, and Ruta Skadi took her cloud-pine branch and sprang into the air.

866443.sentence: Ruta Skadi stayed behind them for some way, watching, measuring their strength in case she should need to fight them.

866766.sentence: “Angels! Halt and listen to me! I am the witch Ruta Skadi, and I want to talk to you!”   They turned.

867956.sentence: “Whose call?”  she said. “A man’s.” “Lord Asriel’s?” “It may be.” “Why are you following his call?”

868183.sentence: Ruta Skadi was four hundred and sixteen years old, with all the pride and knowledge of an adult witch queen.

869430.sentence: The light Ruta Skadi saw them by was still not that of the sun now climbing the  sky, but some other light from somewhere else.

870126.sentence: And she rejoiced, too, that she was going to see Lord Asriel again.

870357.sentence: And at some point the quality of the air changed, not for the worse or the better, but changed nonetheless, and Ruta Skadi knew that they’d passed out of that world and into another.

870745.sentence: Ruta Skadi couldn’t see the invisible gateway, but she didn’t need to: witches could navigate better than birds.

871090.sentence: “Lord Asriel is in this world, and there is the fortress he’s building....”

872113.sentence: Beneath this colossal fortress, fires glared and furnaces smoked in the darkness of early dawn, and from many miles away Ruta Skadi heard the clang of hammers and the pounding of great mills.

When I looked through one of the doorways earlier today, you can imagine how surprised I was to find it opening into our world, and what’s more, to find you nearby. Providence, dear lady! The security services in this world were preoccupied for years with the Soviet Union—we know it as Muscovy. And although that threat has receded, there are still listening posts and machines trained in that direction, and I’m still in touch with those who run the spies.”

Oh, yes, they know it here as well. There is a team in this very city working on it. And another thing: There was a man who disappeared ten or twelve years ago, in the north, and the security services think he was in possession of some knowledge they badly need—specifically, the location of a doorway between the worlds, such as the one you came through earlier today.
