1088105.sentence: Serafina and Ruta Skadi sprang to their pine branches and followed them upward, but they were left far behind.

1088156.sentence: “Were they like the creatures you saw, Ruta Skadi?”

1088267.sentence: said Serafina as they slowed  down in the middle airs, watching the bright flames diminish toward the horizon.

1088560.sentence: “Bigger, I think, but the same kind. They have no flesh, did you see that? All they are is light. Their senses must be so different from ours.... Serafina Pekkala, I’m leaving you now, to call all the witches of our north together. When we meet again, it will be wartime. Go well, my dear ...”

1088627.sentence: They embraced in midair, and Ruta Skadi turned and sped southward.

1088726.sentence: Serafina watched her go, and then turned to see the last of the gleaming angels disappear far away.

1089272.sentence: Lee Scoresby looked down at the placid ocean to his left and the green shore to his right, and shaded his eyes to search for human life.

1089422.sentence: “And this is a new world?”  he said. “New to those not born in it,”  said Stanislaus Grumman.

1089710.sentence: “As old as yours or mine, otherwise. What Asriel’s done has shaken everything up, Mr. Scoresby, shaken it more profoundly than it’s ever been shaken before. These doorways and windows that I spoke of—they open in unexpected places now. It’s hard to navigate, but this wind is a fair one.”

1089802.sentence: “New or old, that’s a strange world down there,”  said Lee. “Yes,”  said Stanislaus Grumman.

1090509.sentence: A few minutes later, as the balloon drifted on, Lee saw first a lighthouse, then the curve of a stone breakwater, then the towers and domes and red-brown roofs of a beautiful city around a harbor, with a sumptuous building like an opera house in lush gardens, and wide boulevards with elegant hotels, and little streets where blossom- bearing trees hung over shaded balconies.

1090556.sentence: And Grumman was right; there were people there.

1090673.sentence: But as the balloon drifted closer, Lee was surprised to see that they were children. There was not an adult in sight.

1091502.sentence: Lee had to rub his eyes when he saw them first, but there was no doubt about it: columns of mist—or something more tenuous than mist—a thickening of the air.... Whatever they were, the city was full of them; they drifted along the boulevards, they entered houses, they clustered in the squares and courtyards.

1091653.sentence: The farther they drifted over the city, the more Lee could observe the  behavior of these forms.

1091881.sentence: And it was clear that some of the children were of interest to them, and that they followed certain children around: the older children, those who (as far as Lee could see through his telescope) were on the verge of adolescence.

1092289.sentence: “What the hell are those things?”  said Lee. “The people call them Specters.”

1093895.sentence: “Mr. Scoresby, that is the way this world works. And if you want to put an end to cruelty and injustice, you must take me farther on. I have a job to do.”

1093943.sentence: “Seems to me—”  Lee said, feeling for the words,

1094257.sentence: “seems to me the place you fight cruelty is where you find it, and the place you give help is where you see it needed. Or is that wrong, Dr. Grumman? I’m only an ignorant aeronaut. I’m so damn ignorant I believed it when I was told that shamans had the gift of flight, for example. Yet here’s a shaman who hasn’t.”

1094447.sentence: A square stone tower rose directly in their path, and Lee didn’t seem to have noticed.

1094630.sentence: He was perfectly aware of the peril they were in, but he held back from implying that the aeronaut wasn’t.

1094749.sentence: And in perfect time, Lee Scoresby leaned over the side of the basket and pulled the cord on one of the bags of ballast.

1095007.sentence: “You have a strange way about you, Dr. Grumman. You ever spend any time among the witches?”

1095278.sentence: “And among academicians, and among spirits. I found folly everywhere, but there were grains of wisdom in every stream of it. No doubt there was much more wisdom that I failed to recognize. Life is hard, Mr. Scoresby, but we cling to it all the same.”

1095603.sentence: “Tell him what his task is.” “And that’s a task that includes protecting Lyra,”  the aeronaut reminded him. “It will protect all of us.”

1095694.sentence: They flew on, and soon the city was out of sight behind them. Lee checked his instruments.

1096010.sentence: Some way ahead a line of high green hills rose into the haze, and Lee was glad he’d provided plenty of ballast.

1096207.sentence: Hester felt it too, and flicked up her ears, and turned her head so that one gold-hazel eye rested on his face.

1096600.sentence: Grumman had seen it too. “Enemies, Mr. Scoresby?”

1097031.sentence: “There can’t be a doubt. I’m uncertain whether to lose ballast and go higher, to catch the quicker wind, or stay low and be less conspicuous. And I’m thankful that thing’s not a zeppelin; they could overhaul us in a few hours. No, damn it, Dr. Grumman, I’m going higher, because if I was in that balloon I’d have seen this one already; and I’ll bet they have keen eyesight.”

1097106.sentence: He set Hester down again and leaned out to jettison three bags of ballast.

1097170.sentence: The balloon rose at once, and Lee kept the telescope to his eye.

1097623.sentence: “Can you summon a stiffer breeze, Dr. Grumman?”  said Lee.

1097928.sentence: A range of hills rose on the far side, and now that he’d gained some height, Lee saw that they might more truthfully be called mountains.

1097981.sentence: He turned to Grumman, but found him deep in a trance.

1098327.sentence: And whether it was the result of gaining height or whether it was the shaman’s spell, a breath did stir the air on Lee’s face.

1098666.sentence: And as Lee turned the telescope on it again, he saw darker, smaller shapes behind it in the shimmering distance.

1099113.sentence: Grumman sat resting in a corner of the basket while his dæmon groomed her feathers.

1099161.sentence: His eyes were closed, but Lee knew he was awake.

1099212.sentence: “The situation’s like this, Dr. Grumman,”  he said.

1100270.sentence: “I do not want to be caught aloft by those zeppelins. There ain’t no defense; they’d have us down in a minute. Nor do I want to land in the water, by free choice or not; we could float for a while, but they could pick us off with grenades as easy as fishing. “So I want to reach those hills and make a landing. I can see some forest now; we can hide among the trees for a spell, maybe a long time. “And meanwhile the sun’s going down. We have about three hours to sunset, by my calculation. And it’s hard to say, but I think those zeppelins will have closed on us halfway by that time, and we should have gotten to the far shore of this bay. “Now, you understand what I’m saying. I’m going to take us up into those hills and then land, because anything else is certain death. They’ll have made a connection now between this ring I showed them and the Skraeling I killed on Nova Zembla, and they ain’t chasing us this hard to say we left our wallet on the counter. “So sometime tonight, Dr. Grumman, this flight’s gonna be over. You ever landed in a balloon?”

1100826.sentence: Grumman sat impassively, moving a magical token of feathers and beads from one hand to the other in a pattern that Lee could see had some purposeful meaning.

1100979.sentence: Lee chewed an unlit cigar and sipped cold coffee from a tin flask.

1101213.sentence: The sun settled lower in the sky behind them, and Lee could see the long shade of evening creep along the shore of the bay and up the lower flanks of the hills ahead while the balloon itself, and the mountaintops, were bathed in gold.

1101699.sentence: When they were still a few minutes from making the shore at the foot of the hills, Lee noticed something new in the sky behind the zeppelins.

1102337.sentence: And then a dark green curtain of rain drifted down and hung from the clouds, and the storm seemed to be chasing the zeppelins as they were chasing Lee’s balloon, for the rain swept along toward them from the sea, and as the sun finally vanished, a mighty flash came from the clouds, and several seconds later a crash of thunder so loud it shook the very fabric of Lee’s balloon, and echoed back for a long time from the mountains.

1102707.sentence: Lee let out the breath he’d been holding.

1102815.sentence: Grumman was standing beside him, one hand on the suspension ring, with lines of exhaustion deep in his face.

1102869.sentence: “Did you bring that storm?”  said Lee. Grumman nodded.

1103442.sentence: More lightning flashed around them, and as the storm came closer, Lee began to fear for the gas in his own balloon.

1104002.sentence: “I trust you, Mr. Scoresby,”  said the shaman.

1104293.sentence: The ropes creaked and strained, but Lee had no fear of their giving way.

1104603.sentence: Lee ran through the figures, double-checked them, and then released the last of his ballast.

1105187.sentence: Lee was too cool by nature to rage at fate; his manner was to raise an eyebrow and greet it laconically.

1105485.sentence: He scooped up Hester and tucked her securely into his breast, buttoning the canvas coat up close to keep her in.

1105618.sentence: Grumman sat steady and quiet; his dæmon, wind-torn, clung firmly with her talons deep in the basket rim and her feathers blown erect.

1105688.sentence: “I’m going to take us down, Dr. Grumman,”  Lee shouted above the wind.

1105800.sentence: “You should stand and be ready to jump clear. Hold the ring and swing yourself up when I call.”  Grumman obeyed.

1106140.sentence: Lee gazed down, ahead, down, ahead, checking each dim glimpse against the next, and blinking the rain out of his eyes; for a sudden squall had brought heavy drops at them like handfuls of gravel, and the drumming they made on the gasbag added to the wind’s howl and the lash of the leaves below until Lee could hardly even hear the thunder.

1106794.sentence: The basket was tossing and lurching so violently it was hard to tell if they were going down, and the gusts were so sudden and wayward that they might easily have been blown a long way skyward without knowing; but after a minute or so Lee felt a sudden snag and knew the grapnel had caught on a branch.

1107136.sentence: Lee was used to it and found his balance at once, but the force took Grumman by surprise.

1107259.sentence: However, he didn’t lose his grip on the suspension ring, and Lee could see him safely poised, ready to swing himself clear.

1107669.sentence: “Still there, Dr. Grumman?”  Lee called, for it was impossible to see anything. “Still here, Mr. Scoresby.”

1107882.sentence: said Lee, for they were wildly swaying in the wind, and he could feel the basket settling with little jerks against whatever was holding them up.

1108214.sentence: It crossed Lee’s mind to cut it loose, but if it didn’t fly away altogether, it would hang in the treetops like a banner and give their position away; much better to take it in, if they could.

1108528.sentence: The glare showed Lee an oak trunk, with a great white scar where a branch had been torn away, but torn only partially, for the basket was resting on it near the point where it was still attached to the trunk.

1108701.sentence: “I’ll follow you, Mr. Scoresby,”  said Grumman.

1108879.sentence: And Lee was aware of a powerful flutter of wingbeats as the eagle dæmon settled again on the basket rim. “She can go that far?”

1109203.sentence: Then, with Hester secure in his breast, he threw the rest of the rope over and clambered down till he felt solid ground beneath his feet.

1109393.sentence: The branches grew thick around the trunk; this was a massive tree, a giant of an oak, and Lee muttered a thank- you to it as he tugged on the rope to signal to Grumman that he could descend.

1109714.sentence: The shaman reached the ground. “Did you hear it?”  said Lee.

1109816.sentence: “Yes. Going higher, into the mountains, I think. Congratulations on landing us safely,  Mr. Scoresby.”

1110011.sentence: “We ain’t finished yet. I want to git that gasbag under the canopy before daybreak, or it’ll show up our position from miles away. You up to some manual labor, Dr. Grumman?” “Tell me what to do.”

1110451.sentence: They labored for a long time, and in peril at one point, when the branch that had been supporting the basket finally broke and pitched Lee down with it; but he didn’t fall far, since the gasbag still trailed among the treetops and held the basket suspended.

1110740.sentence: The fall in fact made concealing the gasbag easier, since the lower part of it had been pulled down through the canopy; and working by flashes of lightning, tugging and wrenching and hacking, Lee managed to drag the whole body of the balloon down among the lower branches and out of sight.

1111137.sentence: “This done by magic?”  said Lee, soaked and stiff, easing himself down into the tent and taking the mug Grumman handed him.

1111196.sentence: “No, you can thank the Boy Scouts for this,”  said Grumman.

1111398.sentence: “Do they have Boy Scouts in your world? ‘Be prepared.’ Of all the ways of starting a fire, the best is dry matches. I never travel without them. We could do worse than this as a campsite, Mr. Scoresby.”

1111459.sentence: “You heard those zeppelins again?”  Grumman held up his hand.

1111575.sentence: Lee listened, and sure enough, there was that engine sound, easier to make out now that the rain had eased a little.

1111620.sentence: “They’ve been over twice now,”  said Grumman.

1111871.sentence: It was less bright than lightning, but it was persistent, and Lee knew it for a flare.

1111918.sentence: “Best put out the fire, Dr. Grumman,”  he said,

1112268.sentence: He took a handful of wet earth and pressed it down over the flames, and Lee struggled to lie down in the little tent and closed his eyes. He had strange and powerful dreams.

1112610.sentence: Lee looked for Hester in alarm, and found her sleeping, which never happened, for when he was awake, so was she.

1113003.sentence: Another dream focused on Grumman, too. Lee seemed to see the shaman shaking a feather-trimmed rattle and commanding something to obey him.

1113108.sentence: The something, Lee saw with a touch of nausea, was a Specter, like the ones they’d seen from the balloon.

1113224.sentence: It was tall and nearly invisible, and it invoked such a gut-churning revulsion in Lee that he nearly woke in terror.

1113412.sentence: But Grumman was directing it fearlessly, and coming to no harm either, because the thing listened closely to him and then drifted upward like a soap bubble until it was lost in the canopy.

1113876.sentence: Pinioned in his dream, Lee could neither move nor cry out, and he suffered the terror of the pilot as the man became aware of what was happening to him.

1114162.sentence: The pilot turned his face to Lee and put out a hand, but Lee had no power of movement.

1114676.sentence: And Lee sat and watched helplessly as the zeppelin flew on directly into a scarp of the mountains that rose up before them.

1114865.sentence: Lee pushed back against the seat in horror, but nothing happened to stop it, and at the moment of impact he cried,

1114956.sentence: He was in the tent, safe, and Hester nibbled his chin. He was sweating.

1115076.sentence: The shaman was sitting cross-legged, but a shiver passed over Lee as he saw that the eagle dæmon was not there near him.

1115479.sentence: Some distant flicker picked out the tree trunks and the undersides of dripping leaves, and Lee knew at once what it was: his dream had been true, and a zeppelin pilot had flown into the hillside.

1115556.sentence: “Damn, Lee, you’re twitching like an aspen leaf. What’s the matter with you?”

1115600.sentence: Hester grumbled, and flicked her long ears.

1115647.sentence: “Ain’t you dreaming too, Hester?”  he muttered.

1115783.sentence: “You ain’t dreaming, Lee, you’re seeing. If I’da known you was a seer, I’da cured you a long while back. Now, you cut it out, you hear?”

1115960.sentence: And without the slightest transition he was floating in the air alongside the shaman’s dæmon, Sayan Kötör the osprey.

1116092.sentence: To be in the presence of another man’s dæmon and away from his own affected Lee with a powerful throb of guilt and strange pleasure.

1116380.sentence: They were gliding, as if he too were a bird, on the turbulent updrafts above the forest, and Lee looked around through the dark air, now suffused with a pallid glow from the full moon that occasionally glared through a brief rent in the cloud cover and made the treetops ring with silver.

1116828.sentence: Sayan Kötör was calling them. And in answer they came, every bird in the forest, whether they had been gliding in the hunt on silent wings or roosting asleep; they came fluttering upward in their thousands through the tumbling air.

1117072.sentence: And Lee felt whatever bird nature he was sharing respond with joy to the command of the eagle queen, and whatever humanness he had left felt the strangest of pleasures: that of offering eager obedience to a stronger power that was wholly right.

1117645.sentence: And they streamed toward the airship, the swiftest reaching it first, but none so swiftly as Sayan Kötör; the tiny wrens and finches, the darting swifts, the silent-winged owls—within a minute the craft was laden with them, their claws scrabbling for purchase on the oiled silk or puncturing it to gain a hold.

1118559.sentence: At the last moment Sayan Kötör screamed, and a thunder of wingbeats drowned even the roar of the engine as every bird took off and flew away.

1118780.sentence: Fire, heat, flames ... Lee woke up again, his body as hot as if he’d been lying in the desert sun.

1119122.sentence: Pale gray light seeped in, and Lee propped himself up to find Hester  blinking beside him and the shaman wrapped in a blanket so deeply asleep he might have been dead, had not Sayan Kötör been perched asleep on a fallen branch outside.

1119348.sentence: No engines in the sky, no enemy voices; so Lee thought it might be safe to light the fire, and after a struggle he got it going and brewed some coffee.

1119800.sentence: “We got one more zeppelin to think about before you start fretting about morals, Lee. There’s thirty, forty men with guns all coming for us. Imperial soldiers, what’s more. Survival first, morals later.”

1120173.sentence: Withdraw and wait for full daylight, no doubt, and fly high enough to scan the edge of the forest over a wide area, so he could see when Lee and Grumman broke cover.

1120267.sentence: The osprey dæmon Sayan Kötör awoke, and stretched her great wings above where Lee was sitting.

1120440.sentence: Hester looked up and turned her head this way and that, looking at the mighty dæmon with each golden eye in turn, and a moment later the shaman himself came out of the tent.

1120564.sentence: “A busy day to come. We must leave the forest at once, Mr. Scoresby. They are going to burn it.”

1120639.sentence: Lee looked around incredulously at the soaking vegetation and said, “How?”

1121050.sentence: “You can see that, can you?” “As clearly as you saw what happened to the zeppelins during the night. Pack what you want to carry, and come away now.”  Lee rubbed his jaw.

1121823.sentence: “Why didn’t they do this last night?”  said Lee.

1121995.sentence: Grumman replied, stripping a branch of its leaves so he could use it as a walking stick,

1122549.sentence: Sayan Kötör, flying high, swooped down to tell them how much progress they were making, and how far behind the flames were; though it wasn’t long before they could see smoke above the trees behind them, and then a streaming banner of flame.

1123226.sentence: Gasping, Lee and Grumman forced themselves up the steep slope of rocks and scree.

1123427.sentence: Half the sky was obscured by smoke and heat shimmer, but high above there floated the squat shape of the one remaining zeppelin—too far away, Lee thought hopefully, to see them even through binoculars.

1123697.sentence: Lee pointed, and Grumman said, “My thoughts exactly, Mr. Scoresby.”

1123873.sentence: The men didn’t pause, climbing on as quickly as they could, but Lee said,

1124130.sentence: “For a human being, nothing comes naturally,”  said Grumman.

1124282.sentence: “We have to learn everything we do. Sayan Kötör is telling me that the ravine leads to a pass. If we get there before they see us, we could escape yet.”

1124548.sentence: Hester preferred to find her own way over the rocks, so Lee followed where she led, avoiding the loose stones and moving as swiftly as he could over the larger rocks, making all the time for the little gulch.

1124639.sentence: Lee was anxious about Grumman, because the other man was pale and drawn and breathing hard.

1124918.sentence: How far they could keep going was a question Lee didn’t want to face; but when they were nearly at the entrance to the ravine, and actually on the edge of the dried riverbed, he heard a  change in the sound of the zeppelin.

1125069.sentence: Hester stumbled, even surefooted, firm- hearted Hester stumbled and faltered.

1125169.sentence: Grumman leaned on the stick he carried and shaded his eyes to look back, and Lee turned to look too.

1125748.sentence: Lee and Grumman were six hundred yards above them, and not far from the entrance to the ravine.

1125917.sentence: “They’re after me, Mr. Scoresby,”  said Grumman,

1126077.sentence: “not you. If you give me the rifle and surrender yourself, you’ll survive. They’re disciplined troops. You’ll be a prisoner of war.”  Lee ignored that and said,

1126404.sentence: Grumman nodded. “I had no strength left to bring the fourth one down”

1126515.sentence: “Just tell me before you go,”  said Lee,

1126726.sentence: “because I won’t be easy till I know. What side I’m fighting for I cain’t tell, and I don’t greatly care. Just tell me this: What I’m a-going to do now, is that going to help that little girl Lyra, or harm her?”

1126766.sentence: “It’s going to help her,”  said Grumman.

1127247.sentence: “Because, Dr. Grumman, or John Parry, or whatever name you take up in whatever world you end up in, you be aware of this: I love that little child like a daughter. If I’d had a child of my own, I couldn’t love her more. And if you break that oath, whatever remains of me will pursue whatever remains of you, and you’ll spend the rest of eternity wishing you never existed. That’s how important that oath is.”

1127375.sentence: The shaman held out his hand, and Lee shook it.

1127485.sentence: Then Grumman turned and made his way up the gulch, and Lee looked around for the best place to make his stand.

1127526.sentence: “Not the big boulder, Lee,”  said Hester.

1127779.sentence: There was a roaring in Lee’s ears that had nothing to do with the conflagration in the forest below, or with the laboring drone of the zeppelin trying to rise again.

1128214.sentence: In the old Alamo games, Hester had often been a cougar or a wolf, and once or twice a rattlesnake, but mostly a mockingbird.

1128290.sentence: Now— “Quit daydreaming and take a sight,”  she said. “This ain’t play, Lee.”

1128601.sentence: Behind them, to Lee’s surprise, the zeppelin was still laboring to rise.

1129121.sentence: The zeppelin lurched over to one side. Lee could hear the other engine howling, but the airship was grounded now.

1129229.sentence: Lee could count them, and he did: twenty-five.

1129295.sentence: He had thirty bullets. Hester crept up close to his left shoulder.

1129662.sentence: Hester was no beauty; she was about as plain and scrawny as a hare could be; but her eyes were marvelously colored, gold-hazel flecked with rays of deepest peat brown and forest green.

1130158.sentence: “I will. But hell, I don’t like taking lives, Hester.”

1130309.sentence: “It’s theirs or Lyra’s. I cain’t see how, but we’re connected to that child, and I’m glad of it.”

1130484.sentence: said Hester, and as she spoke, a crack came from his rifle, and chips of stone flew off the boulder a foot from where she crouched.

1130645.sentence: “Well, that makes me feel better about doing this,”  said Lee, and took careful aim. He fired.

1131274.sentence: Lee’s boulder was soon scarred and pitted, and he felt the thud of the bullets as they hit it.

1131379.sentence: Once he saw the fur on Hester’s back ripple as the wind of a bullet passed over it, but she didn’t budge.

1131593.sentence: And after it, in the pause that came, Lee found that he was wounded; there was blood on the rock under his cheek, and his right hand and the rifle bolt were red.

1131717.sentence: Hester moved around to look. “Nothing big,”  she said. “A bullet clipped your scalp.” “Did you count how many fell, Hester?”

1132916.sentence: “Damn, these are men like me,”  he said. “Makes no sense,”  she said. “Do it anyway.” “Do you believe him? Grumman?” “Sure. Plumb ahead, Lee.”

1133064.sentence: Then there was a long silence. Lee fumbled in his pocket and found some more bullets.

1133199.sentence: As he reloaded, he felt something so rare his heart nearly failed; he felt Hester’s face pressed to his own, and it was wet with tears.

1133241.sentence: “Lee, this is my fault,”  she said. “Why?”

1133660.sentence: “Not long now, Hester,”  he muttered, trying to hold still.

1133707.sentence: “The witch, Lee! You said the witch! Remember?”

1133806.sentence: Poor Hester, she was lying now, not crouching tense and watchful as she’d done all his adult life.

1133960.sentence: “Oh, Hester, yeah, the witch. She gave me ...” “Sure she did. The flower.”

1134015.sentence: “In my breast pocket. Fetch it, Hester, I cain’t move.”

1134230.sentence: With a great effort he closed it in his fist and said, “Serafina Pekkala! Help me, I beg ...”

1134327.sentence: The movement died. Hester was failing.

1134378.sentence: “Hester, don’t you go before I do,”  Lee whispered.

1134505.sentence: “Lee, I couldn’t abide to be anywhere away from you for a single second,”  she whispered back. “You think the witch will come?”

1134767.sentence: He thought: It won’t find it there. Hester’s my center.

1134942.sentence: “He’s the one,”  Hester breathed. Lee found it hard to pull the trigger. Everything was hard.

1135311.sentence: “There’s one man left,”  Hester muttered. “He’s a-making for the zeppelin.”

1135411.sentence: And Lee saw him mistily, one soldier of the Imperial Guard creeping away from his company’s defeat.

1135457.sentence: “I cain’t shoot a man in the back,”  Lee said.

1136205.sentence: Lee saw the fireball and heard through the roar in his ears Hester saying,

1136252.sentence: “That’s all of ’em, Lee.”  He said, or thought,

1136373.sentence: She said, “We held ’em off. We held out. We’re a-helping Lyra.”

1137230.sentence: Pantalaimon flew above Lyra’s head for a while until he tired of that, and then he became a little sure-footed mountain sheep, vain of his horns, leaping among rocks while Lyra scrambled laboriously alongside.

1137475.sentence: Will moved on grimly, screwing up his eyes against the glare, ignoring the worsening pain from his hand, and finally reaching a state in which movement alone was good and stillness bad, so that he suffered more from resting than from toiling on.

1138021.sentence: They stayed a few minutes and moved on, and soon afterward, when the sun was at its highest and hottest, Serafina Pekkala darted down to speak to them.

1138202.sentence: “Lee Scoresby needs me. I don’t know why. But he wouldn’t call if he didn’t need my help. Keep going, and I’ll find you.”

1138263.sentence: “Mr. Scoresby?”  said Lyra, excited and anxious. “But where—”

1138347.sentence: But Serafina was gone, speeding out of sight before Lyra could finish the question.

1138517.sentence: Lyra reached automatically for the alethiometer to ask what had happened to Lee Scoresby, but she let her hand drop, because she’d promised to do no more than guide Will.

1139696.sentence: Will longed for that so much that he hardly knew he did.

1139877.sentence: So he couldn’t express that to Lyra now, though she could see it in his eyes, and that was new for her, too, to be quite so perceptive.

1140027.sentence: The fact was that where Will was concerned, she was developing a new kind of sense, as if he were simply more in focus than anyone she’d known before.

1140418.sentence: Will and Lyra got painfully to their feet again and clambered on.

1140495.sentence: “I been cold plenty of times,”  Lyra said, to take her mind off the pursuers,

1141068.sentence: Pantalaimon was a cricket now, and sat on Lyra’s shoulder, too tired to leap or fly.

1141440.sentence: And so they moved on, toward evening. The witch who flew back to spy was called Lena Feldt.

1141958.sentence: And they weren’t from Will’s world, or the world of Cittàgazze, where people’s dæmons were inside them, and where they still looked alive; these men were from her own world, and to see them without dæmons was a gross and sickening horror.

1142178.sentence: Lena Feldt saw a woman, a short-life, graceful in her khaki hunting clothes and as full of life as the golden monkey  who capered along the water’s edge beside her.

1142329.sentence: Lena Feldt hid among the rocks above and watched as Mrs. Coulter spoke to the officer in charge, and as his men put up tents, made fires, boiled water.

1142636.sentence: The witch had been among Serafina Pekkala’s troop who rescued the children at Bolvangar, and she longed to shoot Mrs. Coulter on the spot; but some fortune was protecting the woman, for it was just too far for a bowshot from where she was, and the witch could get no closer without making herself invisible.

1142938.sentence: Confident at last, Lena Feldt went down the rocky slope toward the lake, and as she walked through the camp, one or two blank-eyed soldiers glanced up briefly, but found what they saw too hard to remember, and looked away again.

1143038.sentence: The witch stopped outside the tent Mrs. Coulter had gone into, and fitted an arrow to her bowstring.

1143320.sentence: Inside the tent Mrs. Coulter was talking to a man Lena Feldt hadn’t seen before: an older man, gray-haired and powerful, with a serpent dæmon twined around his wrist.

1144034.sentence: “They know I can give them more nourishment if they let me live than if they consume me. I can lead them to all the victims their phantom hearts desire. As soon as you described them to me, I knew I could dominate them, and so it turns out. And a whole world trembles in the power of these pallid things! But, Carlo,”  she whispered,

1144267.sentence: “No, it isn’t, Carlo; you know it isn’t. You know I can please you more than this.”

1144439.sentence: Little by little the serpent loosened herself and began to flow along the man’s arm toward the monkey.

1144667.sentence: “Ah,”  said the man as the dæmon slipped slowly off his arm and let her weight into the golden monkey’s hands.

1144756.sentence: The monkey raised her slowly to his face and ran his cheek softly along her emerald skin.

1144866.sentence: “Carlo, tell me why you’re pursuing the boy,”

1144940.sentence: Mrs. Coulter whispered, and her voice was as soft as the monkey’s caress.

1145009.sentence: “Why do you need to find him?” “He has something I want. Oh, Marisa—”

1145064.sentence: “What is it, Carlo? What’s he got?”  He shook his head.

1145265.sentence: But he was finding it hard to resist; his dæmon was twined gently  around the monkey’s breast, and running her head through and through the long, lustrous fur as his hands moved along her fluid length.

1145344.sentence: Lena Feldt watched them, standing invisible just two paces from where they sat.

1145534.sentence: Her bowstring was taut, the arrow nocked to it in readiness; she could have pulled and loosed in less than a second, and Mrs. Coulter would have been dead before she finished drawing breath.

1145698.sentence: But while she was watching Mrs. Coulter, she didn’t look behind her across the little blue lake.

1146204.sentence: But they were not trees, of course; and while all the curiosity of Lena Feldt and her dæmon was directed at Mrs. Coulter, one of the pallid forms detached itself from its fellows and drifted across the surface of the icy water, causing not a single ripple, until it paused a foot from the rock on which Lena Feldt’s dæmon was perched.

1146267.sentence: “You could easily tell me, Carlo,”  Mrs. Coulter was murmuring.

1146587.sentence: “You could whisper it. You could pretend to be talking in your sleep, and who could blame you for that? Just tell me what the boy has, and why you want it. I could get it for you.... Wouldn’t you like me to do that? Just tell me, Carlo. I don’t want it. I want the girl. What is it? Just tell me, and you shall have it.”

1146815.sentence: “It’s a knife. The subtle knife of Cittàgazze. You haven’t heard of it, Marisa? Some people call it teleutaia makhaira, the last knife of all. Others call it Æsahættr.”

1146859.sentence: “What does it do, Carlo? Why is it special?”

1147073.sentence: “Ah ... It’s the knife that will cut anything. Not even its makers knew what it could do. Nothing, no one, matter, spirit, angel, air—nothing is invulnerable to the subtle knife. Marisa, it’s mine, you understand?”

1147130.sentence: “Of course, Carlo. I promise. Let me fill your glass ...”

1147492.sentence: And as the golden monkey slowly ran his hands along the emerald serpent again and again, squeezing just a little, lifting, stroking as Sir Charles sighed with pleasure, Lena Feldt saw what was truly happening: because while the man’s eyes were closed, Mrs. Coulter secretly tilted a few drops from a small flask into the glass before filling it again with wine.

1147751.sentence: And then, without any warning, Mrs. Coulter stood up and turned and looked Lena Feldt full in the face.

1147922.sentence: Lena Feldt was too surprised to move. Behind her, the man was struggling to breathe.

1148021.sentence: His chest was heaving, his face was red, and his dæmon was limp and fainting in the monkey’s hands.

1148144.sentence: The monkey shook her off in contempt. Lena Feldt tried to swing her bow up, but a fatal paralysis had touched her shoulder.

1148315.sentence: “Oh, it’s too late for that,”  said Mrs. Coulter. “Look at the lake, witch.”

1148537.sentence: Lena Feldt turned and saw her snow bunting dæmon fluttering and shrieking as if he were in a glass chamber that was being emptied of air; fluttering and falling, slumping, failing, his beak opening wide, gasping in panic.

1148782.sentence: Even in her sickened distress, Lena Feldt could see that Mrs. Coulter had more force in her soul than anyone she had ever seen.

1148896.sentence: It didn’t surprise her to see that the Specter was under Mrs. Coulter’s power; no one could resist that authority.

1148943.sentence: Lena Feldt turned back in anguish to the woman.

1149037.sentence: “We’ll see. Is the child with you? The girl Lyra?”

1149527.sentence: Lena Feldt told her everything. She could have resisted any torture but what was happening to her dæmon now.

1149655.sentence: When Mrs. Coulter had learned all she wanted to know about where the witches were, and how they guarded Lyra and Will, she said,

1149899.sentence: “And now tell me this. You witches know something about the child Lyra. I nearly learned it from one of your sisters, but she died before I could complete the torture. Well, there is no one to save you now. Tell me the truth about my daughter.”

1149994.sentence: Lena Feldt gasped, “She will be the mother—she will be life—mother—she will disobey—she will—”

1150092.sentence: “Name her! You are saying everything but the most important thing! Name her!”  cried Mrs. Coulter.

1150169.sentence: “Eve! Mother of all! Eve, again! Mother Eve!”  stammered Lena Feldt, sobbing.

1150486.sentence: “Why, I shall have to destroy her,”  said Mrs. Coulter,

1150677.sentence: Lena Feldt, whimpering, heard her go on:

1150852.sentence: “Of course. Asriel will make war on the Authority, and then.... Of course, of course. As before, so again. And Lyra is Eve. And this time she will not fall. I’ll see to that.”

1150956.sentence: And Mrs. Coulter drew herself up, and snapped her fingers to the Specter feeding on the witch’s dæmon.

1151162.sentence: The little snow bunting dæmon lay twitching on the rock as the Specter moved toward the witch herself, and then whatever Lena Feldt had undergone before was doubled and trebled and multiplied a hundredfold.

1151705.sentence: So Lena Feldt failed to see or to care about what Mrs. Coulter did next.

1152352.sentence: She raised her arms and made them forget they were earthbound, so that one by one they rose into the air and floated free like malignant thistledown, drifting up into the night and borne by the air currents toward Will and Lyra and the other witches; but Lena Feldt saw nothing of it.

1152528.sentence: The temperature dropped quickly after dark, and when Will and Lyra had eaten the last of their dry bread, they lay down under an overhanging rock to keep warm and try to sleep.

1152702.sentence: At least Lyra didn’t have to try; she was unconscious in less than a minute, curled tightly around Pantalaimon, but Will couldn’t find sleep, no matter how long he lay there.

1153422.sentence: So he cried, but he lay very still as he did, not wanting to wake Lyra.

1153778.sentence: Behind him the sentry witch’s robin dæmon cocked his head, and she turned from the watch she was keeping to see Will clambering up the rocks.

1154517.sentence: He climbed higher and higher, hardly once thinking of how he might find his way back down to Lyra, until he came out on a little plateau almost at the top of the world, it seemed.

1154984.sentence: In less than a minute Will found himself in nearly total darkness.

1155041.sentence: And at the same moment Will felt a grip on his right arm.

1155143.sentence: He cried out with shock and twisted away at once, but the grip was tenacious. And Will was savage now.

1155925.sentence: Then Will kicked again and again, and some of the kicks connected and some didn’t, and all the time he was pulling, jerking, twisting, shoving, and still the grip held him fast.

1156137.sentence: Dimly he heard his own panting and the man’s grunts and harsh breathing; and then by chance he got his leg behind the man’s and hurled himself against his chest, and the man fell with Will on top of him, heavily.

1156382.sentence: But never for a moment did that grip slacken, and Will, rolling around violently on the stony ground, felt a heavy fear tighten around his heart: this man would never let him go, and even if he killed him, his corpse would still be holding fast.

1156562.sentence: But Will was weakening, and now he was crying, too, sobbing bitterly as he kicked and tugged and beat at the man with his head and feet, and he knew his muscles would give up soon.

1156890.sentence: He was lying there letting Will batter at him with knees and head; and as soon as Will saw that, the last of his strength left him, and he fell helpless beside his opponent, every nerve in his body ringing and dizzy and throbbing.

1157016.sentence: Will hauled himself up painfully, peered through the deep darkness, and made out a blur of white on the ground beside the man.

1157210.sentence: Will tried to pull away, and his feeble tug woke a response from the man, whose hand hadn’t loosened.

1157290.sentence: But he was moving. He was feeling Will’s right hand carefully with his free one.

1157334.sentence: Will’s hair stood on end. Then the man said,

1157386.sentence: “Give me your other hand.” “Be careful,”  said Will.

1157580.sentence: The man’s free hand felt down Will’s left arm, and his fingertips moved gently over the wrist and on to the swollen palm and with the utmost delicacy on to the stumps of Will’s two lost fingers.

1157802.sentence: Will sensed that he was badly hurt. Had he wounded this dark opponent?

1157852.sentence: Will was still lying on the stones, utterly spent.

1158214.sentence: “What are you doing?”  Will said. “Curing your wound. Keep still.” “Who are you?”

1158403.sentence: The wind was beating more wildly than ever, and a drop or two of rain splashed onto Will’s face.

1158789.sentence: Will, still bemused by the blessed cool numbness in his hand, tried to sit up and look at him. But it was darker than ever.

1160159.sentence: “They never knew what they were making, those old philosophers. They invented a device that could split open the very smallest  particles of matter, and they used it to steal candy. They had no idea that they’d made the one weapon in all the universes that could defeat the tyrant. The Authority. God. The rebel angels fell because they didn’t have anything like the knife; but now ...”

1160212.sentence: “I didn’t want it! I don’t want it now!”  Will cried.

1160694.sentence: “Have you won your fights?”  Will was silent. Then he said, “Yes, I suppose.”

1160889.sentence: Will knew that the man was speaking the truth.

1161029.sentence: The man seemed to know that, because he let Will bow his head before he spoke again.

1161964.sentence: And then Stanislaus Grumman, Jopari, John Parry hesitated.

1162084.sentence: He was painfully aware of the oath he’d sworn to Lee Scoresby, and he hesitated before he broke it; but break it he did.

1162123.sentence: “You must go to Lord Asriel,”  he said,

1162493.sentence: “and tell him that Stanislaus Grumman sent you, and that you have the one weapon he needs above all others. Like it or not, boy, you have a job to do. Ignore everything else, no matter how important it seems, and go and do this. Someone will appear to guide you; the night is full of angels. Your wound will heal now—Wait. Before you go, I want to look at you properly.”

1162910.sentence: Will saw blazing blue eyes in a haggard face with several days’ growth of beard on the stubborn jaw, gray-haired, drawn with pain, a thin body hunched in a heavy cloak trimmed with feathers.

1163434.sentence: But in that same moment, as the lantern light flared over John Parry’s face, something shot down from the turbid sky, and he fell back dead before he could say a word, an arrow in his failing heart.

1163503.sentence: The osprey dæmon vanished in a moment. Will could only sit stupefied.

1163816.sentence: “No! No!”  cried the witch Juta Kamainen, and fell down after him, clutching at her own heart, crashing clumsily into the rocky ground and struggling up again.

1163906.sentence: But Will was there before she could find her feet, and the subtle knife was at her throat.

1164142.sentence: And because she was a witch she wouldn’t have been afraid of a boy, normally. But she was afraid of Will.

1165203.sentence: Then she looked back at Will and shook her head sadly.

1165484.sentence: And before Will could stop her, she fell softly sideways, her hand on the hilt of the knife she had just taken from her own belt and pushed between her ribs.

1165536.sentence: Will felt no horror, only desolation and bafflement.

1165806.sentence: Will turned back to the dead man, his father.

1166279.sentence: The little lantern still flickered and flared as the draft through the ill-fitting window licked around the flame, and by its light Will knelt and put his hands on the man’s body, touching his face, his shoulders, his chest, closing his eyes, pushing the wet gray hair off his forehead, pressing his hands to the rough cheeks, closing his father’s mouth, squeezing his hands.

1166649.sentence: “Dad, Daddy ... Father ... I don’t understand why she did that. It’s too strange for me. But whatever you wanted me to do, I promise, I swear I’ll do it. I’ll fight. I’ll be a warrior. I will. This knife, I’ll take it to Lord Asriel, wherever he is, and I’ll help him fight that enemy. I’ll do it. You can rest now. It’s all right. You can sleep now.”

1166913.sentence: Will picked them up, and then he noticed his father’s feather-trimmed cloak trailing behind his body on the ground, heavy and sodden but warm.

1166979.sentence: His father had no more use for it, and Will was shaking with cold.

1167600.sentence: The stormy air was electric with whispers, and in the tearing of the wind Will could hear other sounds, too: confused echoes of cries and chanting, the clash of metal on metal, pounding wingbeats that one moment sounded so close they might actually be inside his head, and the next so far away they might have been on another planet.

1167842.sentence: And as he turned down the last little gully before the place where he’d left Lyra sleeping, he stopped suddenly.

1168006.sentence: Will put his hand on the knife. Then one of the figures spoke. “You’re the boy with the knife?”

1168158.sentence: “Who are you?”  Will said. “Are you men, or—”

1168264.sentence: Will was silent. The speaker went on:

1168513.sentence: “Other angels have other functions, and other powers. Our task is simple: We need you. We have been following the shaman every inch of his way, hoping he would lead us to you, and so he has. And now we have come to guide you in turn to Lord Asriel.”

1168766.sentence: “We would have done, earlier. But his task was over once he’d led us to you.”  Will said nothing.

1168927.sentence: “I’ll come with you. But first I must wake Lyra.”

1169131.sentence: They stood aside to let him pass, and he felt a tingle in the air as he went close to them, but he ignored it and concentrated on getting down the slope toward the little shelter where Lyra was sleeping.

1169258.sentence: But something made him stop. In the dimness, he could see the witches who had been guarding Lyra all sitting or standing still.

1169593.sentence: There were several black-silk-clad bodies on the ground, too, and as he gazed in horror from one to another of them, Will saw what must have happened: they had been attacked in midair by the Specters, and had fallen to their deaths, indifferently.

1169681.sentence: The hollow under the rock was empty. Lyra was gone.

1169873.sentence: It was Lyra’s little canvas rucksack, and from the weight of it he knew without looking that the alethiometer was still inside it.

1169981.sentence: Will was shaking his head. It couldn’t be true, but it was: Lyra was gone, Lyra was captured, Lyra was lost.

1170260.sentence: “You must come with us now. Lord Asriel needs you at once. The enemy’s power is growing every minute. The shaman has told you what your task is. Follow us and help us win. Come with us. Come this way. Come now.”

1170358.sentence: And Will looked from them to Lyra’s rucksack and back again, and he didn’t hear a word they said.

1174332.sentence: The sunlight lay heavy and rich on his lustrous golden fur, and his monkey hands turned a pine cone this way and that, snapping off the scales with sharp fingers and scratching out the sweet nuts.

1174466.sentence: Behind him, just beyond the point where the sunlight reached, Mrs. Coulter was heating some water in a small pan over a naphtha stove.

1174528.sentence: Her dæmon uttered a warning murmur and Mrs. Coulter looked up.

1174662.sentence: Mrs. Coulter knew who she was: Ama had been bringing her food for some days now.

1174818.sentence: Mrs. Coulter had let it be known when she first arrived that she was a holy woman engaged in meditation and prayer, and under a vow never to speak to a man.

1174868.sentence: Ama was the only person whose visits she accepted.

1174999.sentence: Her father was with her, and while Ama climbed up to the cave, he waited a little way off.

1175039.sentence: Ama came to the cave entrance and bowed.

1175142.sentence: “My father sends me with prayers for your goodwill,”  she said. “Greetings, child,”  said Mrs. Coulter.

1175236.sentence: The girl was carrying a bundle wrapped in faded cotton, which she laid at Mrs. Coulter’s feet.

1175496.sentence: Mrs. Coulter understood some of the language of these mountain people, but it would never do to let them know how much.

1175738.sentence: The golden monkey was holding out his little black hand, and Ama’s butterfly dæmon was fluttering closer and closer until he settled on a horny forefinger.

1175881.sentence: The monkey brought him slowly to his ear, and Mrs. Coulter felt a tiny stream of understanding flow into her mind, clarifying the girl’s words.

1176168.sentence: Was this other being Mrs. Coulter’s master, or her servant?

1176310.sentence: Ama conveyed these questions with a thousand misgivings.

1176398.sentence: A novel answer occurred to Mrs. Coulter as the dæmon’s understanding filtered into hers.

1176991.sentence: Ama was half-soothed by Mrs. Coulter’s soft voice, and half-afraid still; and the talk of enchanters and spells added to the awe she felt.

1177119.sentence: But the golden monkey was holding her dæmon so gently, and she was curious, besides, so she followed Mrs. Coulter into the cave.

1177350.sentence: Mrs. Coulter lit a candle, because the light was fading rapidly, and led Ama to the back of the cave.

1177537.sentence: Ama’s eyes glittered widely in the gloom, and her hands were moving together in a repetitive gesture of finger on thumb, finger on thumb, to ward off danger by confusing the evil spirits.

1177668.sentence: Ama looked at the figure in the sleeping bag.

1177820.sentence: It was a girl older than she was, by three or four years, perhaps; and she had hair of a color Ama had never seen before—a tawny fairness like a lion’s.

1178231.sentence: The golden monkey was tenderly smoothing the fur between the sleeping dæmon’s ears, and as Ama looked, the mongoose creature stirred uneasily and uttered a hoarse little mew.

1178332.sentence: Ama’s dæmon, mouse-formed, pressed himself close to Ama’s neck and peered fearfully through her hair.

1178402.sentence: “So you can tell your father what you’ve seen,”  Mrs. Coulter went on.

1178732.sentence: “No evil spirit. Just my daughter, asleep under a spell, and in my care. But, please, Ama, tell your father that this must be a secret. No one but you two must know Lyra is here. If the enchanter knew where she was, he would seek her out and destroy her, and me, and everything nearby. So hush! Tell your father, and no one else.”

1178858.sentence: She knelt beside Lyra and smoothed the damp hair back from the sleeping face before bending low to kiss her daughter’s cheek.

1179000.sentence: Then she looked up with sad and loving eyes, and smiled at Ama with such brave, wise compassion that the little girl felt tears fill her gaze.

1179125.sentence: Mrs. Coulter took Ama’s hand as they went back to the cave entrance, and saw the girl’s father watching anxiously from below.

1179338.sentence: The woman put her hands together and bowed to him, and he responded with relief as his daughter, having bowed both to Mrs. Coulter and to the enchanted sleeper, turned and scampered down the slope in the twilight.

1179538.sentence: Mrs. Coulter turned back to the water on her stove, which was nearly at the boil.

1180027.sentence: Around her there lay some of the equipment from the camp by the blue lake where Sir Charles Latrom had died: a sleeping bag, a rucksack with changes of clothes and washing equipment, and so on.

1180395.sentence: The monkey dæmon dropped his pine cone and came with her.

1180485.sentence: Mrs. Coulter placed the beaker carefully on a low rock and knelt beside the sleeping Lyra.

1180572.sentence: The golden monkey crouched on her other side, ready to seize Pantalaimon if he woke up.

1180638.sentence: Lyra’s hair was damp, and her eyes moved behind their closed lids.

1180793.sentence: She was beginning to stir: Mrs. Coulter had felt her eyelashes flutter when she’d kissed her, and knew she didn’t have long before Lyra woke up altogether.

1180993.sentence: Lyra’s lips parted and she moaned softly; Pantalaimon moved a little closer to her breast.

1181113.sentence: The golden monkey’s eyes never left Lyra’s dæmon, and his little black fingers twitched at the edge of the sleeping bag.

1181185.sentence: A look from Mrs. Coulter, and he let go and moved back a hand’s breadth.

1181361.sentence: The woman gently lifted her daughter so that her shoulders were off the ground and her head lolled, and then Lyra caught her breath and her eyes half-opened, fluttering, heavy.

1181429.sentence: “Roger ... where are you ... I can’t see ...”

1181578.sentence: Holding the beaker in Lyra’s mouth, she tilted it to let a drop moisten the girl’s lips.

1181777.sentence: Lyra’s tongue sensed it and moved to lick them, and then Mrs. Coulter let a little more of the liquid trickle into Lyra’s mouth, very carefully, letting her swallow each sip before allowing her more.

1181885.sentence: It took several minutes, but eventually the beaker was empty, and Mrs. Coulter laid her daughter down again.

1181968.sentence: As soon as Lyra’s head lay on the ground, Pantalaimon moved back around her throat.

1182142.sentence: The golden monkey picked his way lightly to the mouth of the cave and sat once more watching the path.

1182322.sentence: Mrs. Coulter dipped a flannel in a basin of cold water and mopped Lyra’s face, and then unfastened the sleeping bag and washed Lyra’s arms and neck and shoulders, for Lyra was hot.

1182455.sentence: Then her mother took a comb and gently teased out the tangles in Lyra’s hair, smoothing it back from her forehead, parting it neatly.

1182655.sentence: She left the sleeping bag open so the girl could cool down, and unfolded the bundle that Ama had brought: some flat loaves of bread, a cake of compressed tea, some sticky rice wrapped in a large leaf.

1183703.sentence: The golden monkey was right. She wasn’t only hiding Lyra: she was hiding her own eyes.

1183810.sentence: Out of the dark the little boy came, hopeful and frightened, whispering over and over: “Lyra—Lyra—Lyra ...”

1184663.sentence: “Lyra ...”   Why were they there? They were imprisoned.

1184828.sentence: Why did the little boy keep calling Lyra’s name?

1184910.sentence: And Lyra couldn’t touch them, no matter how she tried.

1185057.sentence: “Roger,”  she said, but her voice came out in a whisper.

1185114.sentence: “Oh, Roger, where are you? What is this place?”  He said,

1185336.sentence: “It’s the world of the dead, Lyra—I dunno what to do—I dunno if I’m here forever, and I dunno if I done bad things or what, because I tried to be good, but I hate it, I’m scared of it all, I hate it—”  And Lyra said, “I’ll

1185518.sentence: “Be quiet,”  said Will. “Just be quiet. Don’t disturb me.”

1185653.sentence: It was just after Lyra had been taken, just after Will had come down from the mountaintop, just after the witch had killed his father.

1185827.sentence: Will lit the little tin lantern he’d taken from his father’s pack, using the dry matches that he’d found with it, and crouched in the lee of the rock to open Lyra’s rucksack.

1186150.sentence: “Come with us. You must come. Come now to Lord Asriel.”

1186335.sentence: Will said fiercely. “He told me to expect you. He knew more than you thought. Who sent you?”

1186477.sentence: “We want to serve Lord Asriel. And the dead man, what did he want you to do with the knife?”

1186605.sentence: Will had to hesitate. “He said I should take it to Lord Asriel,”  he said. “Then come with us.” “No. Not till I’ve found Lyra.”

1187179.sentence: “No. If I’m stronger, you have to obey me. Besides, I have the knife. So I can command you: help me find Lyra. I don’t care how long it takes, I’ll find her first and then I’ll go to Lord Asriel.”

1187320.sentence: Then they drifted away and spoke together, though Will could hear nothing of what they said.

1187560.sentence: Will tried to pierce the darkness and see them more clearly, but the rain filled his  eyes.

1188014.sentence: “Well, if I can’t see you, no one else will, either, so you can stay hidden. Go and see if you can find where Lyra’s gone. She surely can’t be far away. There was a woman— she’ll be with her—the woman took her. Go and search, and come back and tell me what you see.”

1188214.sentence: Will felt a great sullen heaviness settle over him; he’d had little strength left before the fight with his father, and now he was nearly finished.

1188483.sentence: Will heard it in the depths of sleep and struggled to wake.

1189549.sentence: “That’s who it is. Mrs. Coulter must have killed him. Well, that’s something good, at least.”

1189717.sentence: Will got to his feet and looked around.

1189957.sentence: The storm had cleared the air, and the morning was fresh and clean, which only made the scene around him more distressing; for nearby lay the bodies of several of the witches who had escorted him and Lyra toward the meeting with his father.

1190116.sentence: Already a brutal-beaked carrion crow was tearing at the face of one of them, and Will could see a bigger bird circling above, as if choosing the richest feast.

1190253.sentence: Will looked at each of the bodies in turn, but none of them was Serafina Pekkala, the  queen of the witch clan, Lyra’s particular friend.

1190675.sentence: Will looked to his left, where the voice was, but saw nothing.

1190912.sentence: “Yes, we do. My name is Balthamos. My companion is Baruch.”  Will considered what to do.

1191083.sentence: At the moment all Will’s choices existed at once.

1191506.sentence: It was only when he’d been walking for several minutes down the pathless, rocky slope that Will realized his hand wasn’t hurting.

1193060.sentence: “Balthamos?” “Always here.” “Where is the dead man?” “Beyond the high rock on your right.” “Are there any Specters around?”

1193258.sentence: Will took up his rucksack and cloak and made his way along the edge of the lake and up onto the rock Balthamos had pointed out.

1193427.sentence: Will moved down warily in case there was someone still alive and hiding.

1194599.sentence: Will walked carefully around to the entrance, which faced the lake.

1194833.sentence: Sprawled beside an overturned canvas chair was the body of the man known in Will’s world as Sir Charles Latrom, and in Lyra’s as Lord Boreal, the man who stole her alethiometer, which theft in turn led Will to the subtle knife itself.

1194907.sentence: Sir Charles had been smooth, dishonest, and powerful, and now he was dead.

1195108.sentence: His face was distorted unpleasantly, and Will didn’t want to look at it, but a glance inside the tent showed that there were plenty of things to steal, so he stepped over the body to look more closely.

1195204.sentence: His father, the soldier, the explorer, would have known exactly what to take. Will had to guess.

1195949.sentence: He packed it all in his rucksack, cut another sliver of meat, filled his belly and then his canteen from the lake, and said to Balthamos:

1196284.sentence: “Baruch was a man. I was not. Now he is angelic.” “So—”

1196421.sentence: Will stopped what he was doing, which was arranging his rucksack so the heaviest objects were in the bottom, and tried to see the angel.

In short, I would say that the Society of the Work of the Holy Spirit will find out very soon where the child is, but they will do nothing about it. They intend to move the Authority secretly away from the Clouded Mountain, to a permanent citadel somewhere else, and turn the mountain into an engine of war. 1279010.sentence: “This, then, is the state of things. There seem to be several points to bear in mind. “Firstly, Lord Asriel. A witch friendly to the Church reports that he is assembling a great army, including forces that may be angelic. His intentions, as far as the witch knows, are malevolent toward the Church, and toward the Authority himself. “Secondly, the Oblation Board. Their actions in setting up the research program at Bolvangar, and in funding Mrs. Coulter’s activities, suggest that they are hoping to replace the Consistorial Court of Discipline as the most powerful and effective arm of the Holy Church. We have been outpaced, gentlemen. They have acted ruthlessly and skillfully. We should be chastised for our laxity in letting it happen. I shall return to what we might do about it shortly. “Thirdly, the boy in Fra Pavel’s testimony, with the knife that can do these extraordinary things. Clearly we must find him and gain possession of it as soon as possible. “Fourthly, Dust. I have taken steps to find out what the Oblation Board has discovered about it. One of the experimental theologians working at Bolvangar has been persuaded to tell us what exactly they discovered. I shall talk to him this afternoon downstairs.”

1279904.sentence: “we must bear our purpose firmly in mind. The Oblation Board sought to understand the effects of Dust; we must destroy it altogether. Nothing less than that. It may be, gentlemen, that the Holy Church itself was brought into being to perform this very task and to perish in the doing of it. But better a world with no Church and no Dust than a world where every day we have to struggle under the hideous burden of sin. Better a world purged of all that!”

Now I want you to devote all your attention to what you remember your colleague saying. Did he make any experiments? Did he leave  any notes? Did he take anyone else into his confidence? We’ll have you moved to somewhere more suitable. Is there anything you need in the way of furnishing, for example? Do you prefer to write at a table or a desk? Would you like a typewriting machine? Perhaps you would rather dictate to a stenographer? “Let the guards know, and you shall have everything you need. But every moment, Dr. Cooper, I want you to think back to your colleague and his theory. Your great task is to recall, and if necessary to rediscover, what he knew. I can protect you with the knife if you’re nearby, but if they attack you up there, I won’t be able to help. And if you die, too, that’ll be the end for me. Balthamos, I need you to help guide me to Lyra. Please don’t forget that. Baruch was strong—be strong, too. Be like him for me.”

1314710.sentence: At first Balthamos didn’t speak, but then he said,

1314800.sentence: “Yes. Yes, of course I must. Sleep now, Will, and I shall stand guard, I shan’t fail you.”

1314865.sentence: Will trusted him; he had to. And presently he fell asleep again.

1315077.sentence: The sun was just rising, and the reeds and the marsh plants were all tipped with gold. Before Will could move, Balthamos said,

1315673.sentence: “I’ve decided what I must do. I shall stay with  you day and night, and do it cheerfully and willingly, for the sake of Baruch. I shall guide you to Lyra, if I can, and then I shall guide you both to Lord Asriel. I have lived thousands of years, and unless I am killed, I shall live many thousands of years more; but I never met a nature that made me so ardent to do good, or to be kind, as Baruch’s did. I failed so many times, but each time his goodness was there to redeem me. Now it’s not, I shall have to try without it. Perhaps I shall fail from time to time, but I shall try all the same.”

1315732.sentence: “Then Baruch would be proud of you,”  said Will, shivering.

1315931.sentence: “fly high, and tell me what the land’s like farther on. Walking on this marshland is going to take forever.”  Balthamos took to the air.

1316179.sentence: He hadn’t told Will everything he was anxious about, because he was trying to do his best and not worry him; but he knew that the angel Metatron, the Regent, from whom they’d escaped so narrowly, would have Will’s face firmly imprinted on his mind.

1316377.sentence: And not only his face, but everything about him that angels were able to see, including parts of which Will himself was not aware, such as that aspect of his nature Lyra would have called his dæmon.

1316512.sentence: Will was in great danger from Metatron now, and at some time Balthamos would have to tell him; but not quite yet. It was too difficult.

1316744.sentence: Will, reckoning that it would be quicker to get warm by walking than by gathering fuel and waiting for a fire to catch, simply slung the rucksack over his shoulders, wrapped the cloak around everything, and set off toward the south.

1317007.sentence: Sometime later, when the light was brighter, Balthamos’s voice spoke beside him.

1317332.sentence: “Good,”  said Will fervently. “And does this path go to the town?”

1317801.sentence: Will walked on. The toil was dull and mechanical, but at least he was moving, and at least every step took him closer to Lyra.

1318856.sentence: Balthamos, being a dæmon, had taken the form of a large snow white dog with black eyes, thick fur, and tight-curled tail, and he snarled so fiercely that the real dogs kept their distance.

1318950.sentence: They were thin and mangy, and the few reindeer Will could see were scabby-coated and listless.

1319120.sentence: Will paused in the center of the little village and looked around, wondering where to go, and as he stood there, two or three men appeared ahead and stood staring at him.

1319180.sentence: They were the first people he had ever seen in Lyra’s world.

1319330.sentence: The white dog changed into a sparrow and flew to Will’s shoulder.

1319467.sentence: No one blinked an eye at this: each of the men had a dæmon, Will saw, dogs, most of them, and that was how things happened in this world.

1319604.sentence: On his shoulder, Balthamos whispered: “Keep moving. Don’t look them in the eye. Keep your head down. That is the respectful thing to do.”

1319688.sentence: Will kept walking. He could make himself inconspicuous; it was his greatest talent.

1319949.sentence: Balthamos said softly, “The priest. You will have to be polite to him. Turn and bow.”  Will did so.

1320125.sentence: His restless eyes moved over Will’s face and body, taking everything in.

1320179.sentence: He beckoned. Will went to the doorway and bowed again.

1320229.sentence: The priest said something, and Balthamos murmured,

1320335.sentence: “I speak English,”  Will said slowly and clearly.

1320657.sentence: “My name is Will, and I’m going south. I have lost my family, and I’m trying to find them again.”

1320969.sentence: But the angel was equal to that: he became a mouse and crept into Will’s shirt as if he were shy.

1321207.sentence: “Will Parry. But I don’t know what to call you.” “Otyets Semyon,”

1321273.sentence: said the priest, stroking Will’s arm as he guided him to a chair.

1321447.sentence: “Otyets means Father. I am a priest of the Holy Church. My given name is Semyon, and the name of my father was Boris, so I am Semyon Borisovitch. What is your father’s name?”

1321608.sentence: “John Parry.” “John is Ivan. So you are Will Ivanovitch, and I am Father Semyon Borisovitch. Where have you come from, Will Ivanovitch, and where are you going?”

1322288.sentence: “A soldier? An explorer from England? No one so interesting as that has trodden the dirty roads of Kholodnoye for centuries, but in this time of upheaval, how can we know that he will not appear tomorrow? You yourself are a welcome visitor, Will Ivanovitch. You must stay the night in my house and we will talk and eat together. Lydia Alexandrovna!”  he called. An elderly woman came in silently.

1322487.sentence: She brought the glass of tea to Will, together with a little saucer of jam with a silver spoon.

1322567.sentence: “Thank you,”  said Will. “The conserve is to sweeten the tea,”  said the priest.

1322703.sentence: The result was that the tea was sickly as well as bitter, but Will sipped it, nonetheless.

1322904.sentence: In order to distract him, Will asked why the buildings in the village sloped.

1323552.sentence: “It is all foretold in the Apocalypse of St. John. Rivers flow backward ... The great river only a short way from here used to flow north into the Arctic Ocean. All the way from the mountains of central Asia it flowed north for thousands and thousands of years, ever since the Authority of God the Almighty Father created the earth. But when the earth shook and the fog and the floods came, everything changed, and then the great river flowed south for a week or more before it turned again and went north. The world is turned upside down. Where were you when the great convulsion came?”

1323587.sentence: “A long way from here,”  Will said.

1323860.sentence: “Bring me that large book on the bottom shelf,”  said Semyon Borisovitch. “I will show you.”

1324298.sentence: He looked closely at the Himalaya, but he could see nothing like the map Baruch had sketched.

1324457.sentence: Semyon Borisovitch talked and talked, pressing Will for details of his life, his family, his home, and Will, a practiced dissembler, answered him fully enough.

1324659.sentence: “Well, how shall we pass our day, Will Ivanovitch?”  said Semyon Borisovitch.

1324789.sentence: He drew another glass of tea from the samovar, and Will took it doubtfully.

1325304.sentence: “Lydia Alexandrovna has a sister who came here and told her there is a boat carrying bears up the river. Armored bears. They come from the Arctic. You did not see armored bears when you were in the north?”

1325407.sentence: The priest was suspicious, and Balthamos whispered so quietly that only Will could hear: “Be careful.”

1325567.sentence: And Will knew at once why he’d said it: his heart had begun to pound when Semyon Borisovitch mentioned the bears, because of what Lyra had told him about them.

1325763.sentence: “Yes, that is what I heard,”  said the priest, to Will’s relief.

1326606.sentence: “But now they are leaving their homeland and coming south. They have a boat, and the people of the town will not let them refuel. They are afraid of the bears. And so they should be—they are children of the devil. All things from the north are devilish. Like the witches—daughters of evil! The Church should have put them all to death many years ago. Witches—have nothing to do with them, Will Ivanovitch, you hear me? You know what they will do when you come to the right age? They will try to seduce you. They will use all the soft, cunning, deceitful ways they have, their flesh, their soft skin, their sweet voices, and they will take your seed—you know what I mean by that—they will drain you and leave you hollow! They will take your future, your children that are to come, and leave you nothing. They should be put to death, every one.”

1326780.sentence: “Now I am going to offer you a little drink, Will Ivanovitch,”  he said.

1327107.sentence: “You are young, so not very many glasses. But you are growing, and so you need to know some things, like the taste of vodka. Lydia Alexandrovna collected the berries last year, and I distilled the liquor, and here in the bottle is the result, the only place where Otyets Semyon Borisovitch and Lydia Alexandrovna lie together!”

1327238.sentence: This kind of talk made Will hideously uneasy. What should he do?

1327982.sentence: He threw back the glass, swallowing it all at once, and then hauled his massive body up and stood very close to Will.

1328230.sentence: In his fat, dirty fingers the glass he held out seemed tiny; but it was brimming with the clear spirit, and Will could smell the heady tang of the drink and the stale sweat and the food stains on the man’s cassock, and he felt sick before he began.

1328305.sentence: “Drink, Will Ivanovitch!”  the priest cried, with a threatening heartiness.

1328391.sentence: Will lifted the glass and unhesitatingly swallowed the fiery, oily liquid in one gulp.

1328567.sentence: Semyon Borisovitch leaned forward from his great height, and took Will by both shoulders.

1328805.sentence: Vapors of tobacco and alcohol and sweat came powerfully from him, and he was close enough for his thick beard, wagging up and down, to brush Will’s face.

1328978.sentence: Will held his breath. The priest’s hands moved behind Will’s shoulders, and then Semyon Borisovitch was hugging him tightly and kissing his cheeks, right, left, right again.

1329047.sentence: Will felt Balthamos dig tiny claws into his shoulder, and kept still.

1329234.sentence: “Go, then,”  he said, “go south, Will Ivanovitch. Go.”

1329668.sentence: Balthamos made him stop at one point, and laid his cool hands on Will’s neck and forehead, and the ache eased a little; but Will made himself a promise that he would never drink vodka again.

1344754.sentence: “The side that gave advantage to the bears. What else? But I have some regard for a few among humans. One was a man who flew a balloon. He is dead. The other is the witch Serafina Pekkala. The third is the child Lyra Silvertongue. First, I would do whatever serves the bears. Second, whatever serves the child, or the witch, or avenges my dead comrade Lee Scoresby. That is why I will help you rescue Lyra Silvertongue from the abominable woman Coulter.”

1345180.sentence: He told Will of how he and a few of his subjects had swum to the river mouth and paid for the charter of this vessel with gold, and hired the crew, and turned the draining of the Arctic to their own advantage by letting the river take them as far inland as it could—and as it had its source in the northern foothills of the very mountains they sought, and as Lyra was imprisoned there, too, things had fallen out well so far.

1345315.sentence: So time went past. During the day Will dozed on deck, resting, gathering strength, because he was exhausted in every part of his being.

1354079.sentence: Lord Asriel’s force, the squadron of gyropters and the zeppelin fuel tanker, had reached the opening between the worlds: the breach in the sky above Svalbard.

1354272.sentence: They had a very long way to go still, but they flew without pause except for essential maintenance, and the commander, the Afric King Ogunwe, kept in twice-daily touch with the basalt fortress.

1354467.sentence: He had a Gallivespian lodestone operator aboard his gyropter, and through him he was able to learn as quickly as Lord Asriel himself about what was going on elsewhere. The news was disconcerting.

1354937.sentence: The Society had a swifter and more skillful alethiometrist than Fra Pavel, and thanks to him, the Consistorial Court now knew exactly where Lyra was, and more: they knew that Lord Asriel had sent a force to rescue her.

1355510.sentence: And they both knew that whoever got there first would have the advantage, but there wasn’t much in it: Lord Asriel’s gyropters were faster than the zeppelins of the Consistorial Court, but they had farther to fly, and they were limited by the speed of their own zeppelin tanker.

1355631.sentence: And there was another consideration: whoever seized Lyra first would have to fight their way out against the other force.

1355776.sentence: It would be easier for the Consistorial Court, because they didn’t have to consider getting Lyra away safely. They were flying there to kill her.

1357143.sentence: The Chevalier Tialys’s clan bred powerful red-and-yellow-striped dragonflies with vigorous and brutal appetites, whereas the one the Lady Salmakia was nurturing would be a slender, fast- flying creature with an electric blue body and the power of glowing in the dark.

So here it is: the truth. “I found out that my daughter is in danger from the very people I used to belong to— from the Church. Frankly, I think they want to kill her. So I found myself in a dilemma, you see: obey the Church, or save my daughter. And I was a faithful servant of the Church, too. There was no one more zealous; I gave my life to it; I served it with a passion. “But I had this daughter ... “I know I didn’t look after her well when she was young. She was taken away from me and brought up by strangers. Perhaps that made it hard for her to trust me. But when she was growing up, I saw the danger that she was in, and three times now I’ve tried to save her from it. I’ve had to become a renegade and hide in this remote place, and I thought we were safe; but now to learn that you found us so easily—well, you can understand, that worries me. The Church won’t be far behind. And they want to kill her, Will. They will not let her live.”

I’m alone, Will, just me in a cave with my daughter, and all the forces of all the worlds are trying to track us down. And here you are, to show how easy it is to find us, apparently. What are you going to do, Will? What do you want?”

I love her so much I’ve given up everything I had—a great career, great happiness, position and wealth—everything, to come to this cave in the mountains and live on dry bread and sour fruit, just so I can keep my daughter alive.
